review_title: good if you want to settle in for life
pros:
fantastic culture, work-life balance, benefits, mostly all pampering..
amazingly professional work environment.. with respect to aspects other than work you can challenge anything and everything and you will be heard for sure.. this place is a home away from home
vertical orgs can be really good to work for but only in techno functional areas..
cons: if you are an activator/performer/disruptive/thinker then stagnancy will haunt you every 2 or less than years.. work progress is very slow.. exposure as a technical person is negligible (mostly in all IT groups) except the tech you are working on (exposure/learning strictly subjected to your own interest; no body will say you a word if you remain av performer even for years), even in that there will be a team to take care of related worries.. its basically a place of talkers, #of doers are so less that you can ignore... two good parts.. 1. if you are lucky and highly patient then instead of just working round the clock, get yourself heard by management- you will shine unless until by then your ego and zeal had not died. 2. this place can be amazing if you are hired at some managerial level- then just settle for life :)

review_title: Redefining review criteria to generate layoff lists, strict no-rehire
job_title: Component Design Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: many opportunities, good potential to build career if you find the right position and good mentor; good benefits and compensation (which you will need for health and mental health management); potentially good "intel values" when they are maintained
cons:
You are out of luck if your project gets canceled for reasons out of your control.
Encourages team members to flee a sinking ship
too many diving catches expected
poor work-life management, massive overwork and stress expected
Fishbowl office space redesign, anti-ADHD; made it easier to lay people off as you have no space for any belongings.
Focal review data abused to generate layoff lists from corporate - first level managers surprised; data assumed correct and good; strict no-rehire policy is short-sighted.
much chaos from endless re-orgs and restructuring. too many geos and too many expectations from all levels to manage projects.
multiple-manager issues - pulled in many directions and you and your direct manager don't know what you're supposed to be doing.
possible age discrimination

pros:
Pays well, in general. If you are with the right group, the even-keeled engineering culture can be inviting. Work-life balance was good.

If you are young and are offered a good job, it might be a good place to get some experience, but keep your options open and keep scanning the marketplace, because you most likely won't get the opportunity to retire there.
cons:
Every two years or so, it seems like they are doing some sort of re-org and priorities change, so it is hard to keep continuity with what one is doing. Some groups seem to value what you are doing for them; others, not so much. You never know what you are going to get. 

This time around, however, management made extremely bad decisions and 11% of the workforce is paying for it (regardless of what upper management wants you to think). So, the culture at present is rather toxic, I've heard. 

There tends to be a lot of political double-speak, phrasing things in palatable sounding business terms where you have to read between the lines to guess what people really think or in a particular situation what might have really happened.

job_title: Component Design Engineer in Folsom, CA
pros: diversified work-life balance career opportunities
cons: I havent seen any cons until now

pros: all good, befits, bonus, shares
cons: all good but hard to get forward

review_title: Terrible company and has tons of politics
pros: Nothing good about this company
cons: They don't have interest in helping NCG's, toxic work environment, and a lot of politics

review_title: Excellent company - Empowering, supportive and flexible
pros:
- Respects and supports "best" or right idea, over needing to push self in order to get credit
- Tends towards flexible working conditions.
- 1 month off every 4 years!
- Bonuses tend to be about one's level, their group, and how the company does overall instead of a cut throat, "me first", system.
- Bonus schedule (every 3 months and larger, once a year) is nice.
- Respects employees, empowers them to improve the company and ecosystem.
- Filled with very smart people while maintaining a humble culture.  
- Leadership & Principals tend to treat others as equals.
- Believes in and supports innovation
- Feels comfortable talking to leadership due to their respect and openness.
- Clear initiatives within to grow Intel's culture and benefits to be first in class.
- Overall, one of the best environments I've ever worked in.
cons: Road to career advancement feels long, daunting and a bit like a game instead of based on value. Drives top tier developers to leave for promotions rather than wait years.

pros: nice place, talent people, interesting products
cons: boring work some times, not enough challenging

job_title: Principal Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
Intel is a dominant company in computing - has depth, experience and silicon design and development skills to maintain that for years.
Intel has lots of resources - if it's hardware related and Intel wants in, it's very difficult to prevent it.
x86: 30 years of software investment is tough to walk away from, especially if the performance / price is competitive.
cons:
Intel's leaders generally believe the internal propaganda too much, and buy into hype that their visionary, outstanding leaders.
Internal communication tends to be too often be propaganda, spin or just feel good.
Way too much time is spent telling folks we need to do things differently w/o clear examples, from the person speaking, on what they've done.

review_title: Good learning, good people, unhealthy environment
job_title: Human Resources Manager in Folsom, CA
pros: Everything has a process, Intel University, smart people there who will mentor you, fast-paced and challenging. Used to be a metric driven company
cons: Everything has a process... one of my peers told me 'Intel is where fun goes to die.' I would add... 'and where creativity goes to die.' A student once told me 'why would I work at Intel- it's just a bunch of type A people pissing on each other all day.' Pretty accurate. The culture actually draws out the absolute the worst type A behaviors in people there but of course, it is accepted since the hope is it also draws out the best type A behaviors- long hours, internal competition and confrontation on every little thing

review_title: Not for talented people, insecure managers, no career growth, company is doomed
job_title: Process Engineer, Yield Eng, Senior Program Manager in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Flashy and false outlook for product timeline (14nm technology dragged for several years, Mobile business has no future but management always falsify outlook). They are on-track to reduce the headcounts by 30% within next two years - very bad sign for company's future. No future.
cons: If you have an offer - please keep on looking unless you have given-up and ready for this graveyard. Particularly, if you are going to a manufacturing job/FAB - this will such all your blood, energy, family life as well as your ambitions within your first year. Especially if you have a higher degree (MS. PhD) - you will be exploited just based on the brand-name which really not well respected within industry..as people outside intel well aware that you did develop your career - just did chores which a high-school-er could do. Managers are very insecure and typical clerk ability, regularly needs ego-boosting. They are always feared to save their job so they will not leave any chance to make you a scapegoat. Obvious favoritism...merits and results come last.

pros: Before plunging into high risk work there was very detailed training that prepares employees to work safely and without interrupting production. The team I worked with was very amicable and professional. My manager was excellent and managing workloads and providing flexibility.
cons: Intel is a very large company and so there is a lot of required corporate brainwashing and corporate bureaucracy. Although I came in during a downturn in sales, the cut-back culture remained long after short and long term outlooks improved. If you perform well and are constantly seeking advancement (possibly out of your current role completely), than you will not be impacted. But, if you remain in the same roll for too long you will be susceptible to the cutbacks that seem to hit business groups every 1-2 years.

review_title: Too much normalization - Broken hiring process - Best Work-Life Balance
job_title: SoC Verification Engineer in Boston, MA
pros:
Job security is pretty good unlike other companies.
Work-Life balance for not-so-active folks - this is the Employer you want to join.
Stock value will remain stable because of shareholders.
Internal transfers are easiest (but remember, there no negotiation on your compensation - they offer you the least in that band)
cons:
- Normalization kills your interest to contribute more in the team EVE if you are interested.
- Takes too long to get the project out in market ( I have seen a project which took more than 4 years)
- Decision making in the exec level is a very long process so company is not able to adapt quickly to the market.
- Yearly increment is the lowest you can think of (even if company's stock grew more than 50 in that Financial Year)
They say, 2-6% but mostly it is in between 2-3%
- Hiring process is broken, if you have a reference of any manager/lead you will be interviewed and offered a position
- Hiries to many RCGs for the project which is about to start 24 month from the date
- Office politics is huge, difficult to grow.

pros: Some best reason work with intel
cons: intel is multi national company

job_title: Lab Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Big established company with cache within the industry.  Established culture eases entry into position.  Generally easy to get along with most co-workers and immediate supervisory levels.  Recent perks include free drip coffees, teas, and fountain drinks.  Bonus plans involve entire company, meaning that we improve as an entity and "under-performing" groups do not necessarily get slammed in the bonus process.  Medical benefits options are plentiful, with several choices that one could choose based on needs and cost.  Profit-sharing tends to take a bath when the stock slides, but the 401k setups generally involve funds that are well-managed.  Good people work here...
cons: Pay generally somewhat less than "industry standard", sometimes as much as 20%; medical costs increasing even when company contribution decreases due to overall decrease in benefit cost; extremeny tight-lipped concerning major job-affecting events, to the detriment of the general worker population, even to the point that the board has been concerned; At times it becomes difficult to procure what's needed in order to perform job duties (this is department- and group-dependent) due to some in middle management being more concerned about minimizing costs at a bottom-line level as opposed to suspending or eliminating "nice - to - have" tools, equipment and services...

review_title: Great company, but don't expect much growth
job_title: Software Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Interesting work on market-leading high-tech products. Good work atmosphere and team spirit. Flexible work times. Fair, thorough performance reviews. Good recognition and salaries. Great, very smart co-workers and some great managers at the lower levels.
cons:
Cost cutting is becoming too aggressive for a company that makes billions of profit. This does not help the company's long-term future and (therefore) not the stock price either.

Company is very large and "top-down". Communication and the flow of ideas goes only one way from the top to the bottom. Ideas of young bright people are not taken seriously because these people rank too low in the hierarchy. This is probably a general big-company problem, but Intel is suprisingly poor in mitigating it.

HR department appears to be not on par with that of other comparable high-tech companies. Employees are regarded as an exchangeable commodity. Talent, creativity, and interests do not really matter, because these are soft factors that are not measurable in metrics. If top people leave, just hire a recent college graduate. In high-tech research and development, this thinking hurts.

review_title: Great benefits, lots of toys, fast paced feel, but suffers from having too many EE/CE people.
pros:
-The best corporate cafe in all of Austin hands down. We eat like kings and the food is sold at cost, all of it being prepared by our very own classically trained chefs. It's healthy, always organic, and delicious. 
-The pay is far and away the best you're going to find as an Intern in TX. The benefits are great, plus you can pretty much work there as long as you want (summer, 1 yr, or 2). 
-The have a lot of nice equipment that you usually won't ever get to play with at some smaller companies.
cons:
-The company suffers from having historically only hired EE and CE people. Literally, no one knows how to do anything software related, aside from basic scripting. 
-Because of this, some departments of the company are essentially just thrown together, loosely affiliated confederations of engineers who don't even know that they don't know.
-If you're expecting coding standards, centralized software, i.e. a basic methodology to how a group of people should operate together towards a common goal, you'll instead find a multi-million dollar lab with people doing everything manually.
-Also whenever that person leaves, no one knows how to do what he was doing.

job_title: Process TD Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Hands on development means you have a real opportunity to personally shape the production process before it becomes established worldwide. It's a rare treat to be able to turn an idea into a reality and I feel so grateful just to have this opportunity. The company has great benefits and tries to look out for its employees. There is ample opportunity to make a good name for yourself and build a career that lasts, though it definitely means making hard choices about how your time is spent.
cons: Lots of stress, very little sleep, always working around the clock, low head count - meaning there aren't many people to fill in as backup coverage.  I have a hard time finding any time to groom myself let alone spend any time with my family away from work. Both my mental and physical health are declining from this job. I often wonder if it's really worth it.

review_title: Good company and good locations, but career advancement in marketing is limited due to slow growth
job_title: Senior Product Manager in Portland, OR
pros:
Prestige, career opportunties in tech industry with a solid and fair employer.

Good international business exposure with 70%+ sales overseas.

Can't beat the sabbattical benefit (seven years = 2 months paid time off)

Lots of smart and talented people

Manage your own career depending on how well you can network and do your job
cons:
Company is too big and no longer is a growth company with the career advancement opportunities afforded by such smaller companies.  The stock price is stuck where it was in 1998 so the compensation has not fully adjusted...

Middle and upper management is a mixed bag due to recent stalled growth and lack of formal management training (best engineer or product manager with longest tenure gets job level promotion)

Company can be pretty insular due to size and market position dominance.  Struggled to find growth areas outside of CPUs (desktops, mobile and server businesses are all CPU/chipset based).  Annual focal process can be cumbersome and political.

review_title: Good place to work for a work/life balance
job_title: Senior Design Engineer in Folsom, CA
pros: Compensation is one of the best in the industry. You can make good amount of money from the bonus/stock purchase. Good work enviornment and challenging work in some of the teams. But that may not apply to all teams. Work culture depends on location.. Some locations are laid back and you have a good work life balance where as at some locations it is more aggresive. Good opportunity to make a difference in a product that is used by millions around the world (if its a matter of pride to you). COmpensation not bad if you do well... becomes very good as you progress and do well.
cons: Not so competative enviornment in some of the teams. Also most of the intel locations are small towns which may not attract younger crowd. So Intel may not be your choice. There are too many levels of managment but things have improved in the last one or two years. Not a place to work if you like small teams. Too much dependancy on teams across the world and sometimes getting the job done can take a long time and may need a lot of patience. Intel is not one of the places where compensation is above average but this may change based on your performance.

review_title: Great or Not,  It is up to you
job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Folsom, CA
pros:
Intel is a big place, that means that the opportunities are limitless. You have to be able to network your way to wherever you want to go. Be open and vigilant and you can get some of the most amazing opportunities to do som really cool stuff.  In finance, the rotating program can be a drag or a blessing it is up to you.

Once you develop your skills and let everyone know what you are good at, it mkae it a lot easier to be successful. You can ride your skill and knowledge to the top. I am excited about working here and look forward to significantly advancing my career here.
cons: It is a huge company, it can be a challenge to navigate. No one will baby you around here, you have to be willing to go make things happen by yourself. Once you engage people, you should be fine. Don't expect a lot of hand holding. That is just not part of the culture here.

review_title: Intel has become a very different place
job_title: Soc Design Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros:
Employee friendly and a career company.
Lot of opportunities if you want to try something different. 
Many smart people to work with and a very good place to learn.
cons:
Not sure if it is employee friendly or a career company anymore. 
The CEO seems to be more interested in being on screen and showing flashy things. Many are questioning how these flashy things can be converted into revenue. 
The layoffs and the emphasis on individual performance is encouraging "hunger games" mentality.
Huge disconnect between management and reality seen by people on ground.

pros: Great training program and very specific path for advancement. The Intel culture encourages risk-taking which is great if you want to start side-projects if time-permitting. Managers will give you very specific and helpful feedback at performance reviews which gives you some concrete ideas of what you can do better next quarter. The reviews also outlines key achievements and where you fit in the Intel road map, this is extremely important because sometimes it is difficult to see the impact of your work in such a large company. Work schedule is very flexible as all employee performances are measured by results, not effort.
cons: Contributions to the company may seem small. Although career advancement path is clear, it may be much slower than smaller companies. The work environment is very traditional and office-like. People work in separate cubes, although there are re no closed doors, it still seems like a closed environment. Hillsboro is essentially a farm, it's remote and very quite, but outside of work there is very little to do. Downtown Portland is not too difficult to reach but living in Hillsboro can be boring. Transportation in the Hillsboro area is not convenient, so a car is definitely required. Working at such a remote location makes you feel somewhat isolated.

review_title: Overall, Intel is a decent place to work with fairly good total compensation.
job_title: IT Project Manager in Chandler, AZ
pros: Intel has great total compensation once you add together pay, benefits, stock, options, and bonuses. Even in bad times, there are usually bonuses every year. There are areas at Intel where you can work really hard and get compensated for it, or there are areas that have a good work/life balance, so there's something for everyone. There's at least some level of telecommuting available. If you can convince management of the benefits, you can get a decent level of tuition reimbursement.
cons: There were seemingly constant reorgs, which were time consuming and demoralizing. The good old days of huge stock gains are over. Your yearly review is completely dependent on your individual manager, so if you have a bad one, you are not likely to get the good raises. Intel puts the biggest focus on areas directly related to manufacturing of processors. If you are not in one of those groups, you are often overlooked. Flexible work arrangements which were common in older times were becoming rare due to management influence.

review_title: Big company overshadowed by bureaucracy and bad working atmosphere
pros:
- Big name to put in CV
- They have some engineers with great technical skills to work with.
- Mediorce pay compared to local companies.
cons:
- Intel is already bureaucracy behemoth. To make matters worse, managers are not reluctant to devise new paperworks and meaningless projects just to make them look good and gain more control over engineers and technicians.
- Shark tank working environment. FOCAL performance review kills trust between employees.
- Too much brainwashing about how great Intel is: mangers bullshitting about Intel values, people at quarterly Business Update Meetings (BUM) are really clueless about the company's performance and strategies.
- Too many rules ( no running, don't use laptop without a mouse, use the handrail...) that makes me feel like a prisoner.
- Acronyms are abused. I spent my first months not having a clue what people were talking about.
- Here in Vietnam, people who work on shift are rotated between day shift and night shift everymonth, which everyone hates. Also, the newly built factory here is filled mostly with old machines from other Intel sites- pain in the ass to work with :(

Ready to quit when my contract ends.

pros: Intel, I believe, is still a comfortable place to work at but it is far less influential in tech.  If your goal is to find a job where you just cruise, this might be it.
cons: Intel has a history of having layoffs and in 2015-2016 I know they laid off some highly qualified people just due to age and ethnic background.  A far cry from the company I started with back in 2005 where it was an organization that prided itself as a meritocracy.

review_title: Great company, but business decisions among technical managers could be improved
job_title: Product Development Engineer in Portland, OR
pros: Intel allows freshly minted engineers to put their money where their mouth is and innovate.  For someone who enjoys self guided work, there is a lot of opportunity to demonstrate excellence and receive meritous acknowledgement of your contribution.  You will have a chance to prove yourself and then some.
cons: The quick turns on a product cycle lead meant constant long hours for all engineering staff that frankly didn't end.  Pagers and after hours calls are a practical reality of the job.  There is remarkably little engagement with the factories until it's time for a tech transfer, which dissociates some of the practical decision making from the engineering novelty.  Also, it appeared that there was relatively high "job shift" for incoming engineers to roles outside of development due to a high rate of early burn out.

review_title: After 17 years with the company and a variety of well paying and challenging job,  Intel is a great place for a career.
pros:
Intel:
- influences many parts of the technology ecosystem and an employee can learn and have an impact on many areas over the course of a career. 
- pays competitively and has great benefits
- allows flexibility of work schedule 
- an employee can rise to senior positions based on performance
- for someone with initiative Intel is a great place to work
cons:
Intel: 
- does not stress good people management
- if a person does not have industry experience, Intel can be daunting. It is a large company and an employee needs to take the initiative to learn on their own. 
- Intel invests in many areas outside of the core expertise, semiconductor manufacturing. An employee needs to understand when to follow the company in new areas and when to find employment in other divisions. Many employees have left the company because they were in a group when Intel no longer wished to make investments and lost their job.

review_title: After 17 years with the company and a variety of well paying and challenging job,  Intel is a great place for a career.
pros:
Intel:
- influences many parts of the technology ecosystem and an employee can learn and have an impact on many areas over the course of a career. 
- pays competitively and has great benefits
- allows flexibility of work schedule 
- an employee can rise to senior positions based on performance
- for someone with initiative Intel is a great place to work
cons:
Intel: 
- does not stress good people management
- if a person does not have industry experience, Intel can be daunting. It is a large company and an employee needs to take the initiative to learn on their own. 
- Intel invests in many areas outside of the core expertise, semiconductor manufacturing. An employee needs to understand when to follow the company in new areas and when to find employment in other divisions. Many employees have left the company because they were in a group when Intel no longer wished to make investments and lost their job.

job_title: Manufacturing Technician in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Good pay, compressed work week, great benefits, excellent clean room and manufacturing facilities, and job security, for the most part.
cons: Horrible management. No communication. No loyalty to long time employees. Horrible hiring practices. Care more about making money than making their employees happy, at least on the manufacturing side.

review_title: Performance review are old fashion brag sheets, smooth talkers get recognized. Mature employees no longer valued
job_title: Product Planner in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
Get some experience then move on to better companies like nVidia, Facebook, Apple, Google, etc
Some of the folks are intelligent and great to work with
Stock is now worth something, in $30's
cons:
Hard workers get satisfactory and are over looked. Performance reviews are antiquated
Recent culture is bad, no longer value experienced folks, focus on younger new hires to reinvigorate company ideas.
You need to write a monthly status report of what you did
No subsidized lunch, just free fruit (one serving), free coffee, tea and soda's
Management has no real strategy, just a product roadmap
Used to have a culture of innovation and hard work was valued, now you just push what they want you to work on
Still a lot of arrogance from sister departments and internal arbitrage
Sales force is not as great as it used to be and relies on division to carry them
Decision making is not rapid, expect multiple approval forums

pros: Decent pay and lots of opportunity to improve skills, learn new ones and work in a range of different roles.  Opportunity to work with international teams and can be some interesting travel.  The company offers some very good internal training options in both business and technical areas. There are  lot of very intelligent, talented people working there who are great to work with.  Great people, in fact, is probably the biggest plus about the working experience at this company.
cons: Very long hours are the norm, and not unusual to have to spend part of the weekend getting work done, as well.  Work life balance is very hard to attain and is not really a priority from management perspective.  The performance review process has become cutthroat and political.  Middle management is largely about self-promotion and visibility, so competition is extreme and leads to some ugly practices -- especially re: people management.

pros:
-Some smart people
-Name looks good on resume
-Work/Life balance
cons:
1) We have a TON of non-technical managers (including 1st level managers). This makes no sense. The majority of 1st level managers are non-technical. Therefore, they have no idea what it takes to build great products. Most of them schedule a ton of 1 hour long meetings to get status updates so they can feel important and show 2nd and 3rd level managers that they are bringing value to the team.
2) Lots of low-quality engineers get hired here. The motto at Intel is "We have a headcount, we must fill them all before we lose them." The motto at more successful tech companies is "Let's hire smart people and then we'll figure out where to plug them in."
3) The culture here is not that great. It's a very old-school mentality. There are a ton of people who have been working here for 20+ years (mostly mid-level managers) who don't know anything about the product that their engineers are building. Yet, they are the ones who are making the big decisions.

review_title: Employees are no longer the biggest asset
pros: 4/8 Sabbaticals, paternity leave, facilities, free fruit and drinks for internal employees, employee recognition program, logo, company name or resume
cons: Lack of communication, all about stockholders equity, no clear direction, reactive management. The company I started with back in 2006 is gone. It is extremely frustrating to see how management makes desperately decisions to maintain stockholders returns which translate in cuts. ACT reduced workforce by 10% but we continue to see reductions by collocation, shutdows, etc. leveraging presence in countries such as Costa Rica, India, and China. The company brags about record revenue each and every quarter, yet I have not seen record bonuses nor significant pay increases to compensate employees. I used to think that Intel was a career company with unlimited options; now I am planning on taking my last sabbatical before moving to a different company.

review_title: Intel is a Great Place to Work
pros: Challenging work with highly qualified peers in an intense competitive environment makes Intel a satisfying work environment. Different business groups have different cultures with different operating principles and management culture, so it is best to network with employees before joining. Reputation for long hours, nose to the grindstone is somewhat undeserved now. It is not a place, though, for wallflowers and shrinking violets. The work environment is tough-minded, and critical, but not disrespectful. Management is competent, if not visionary, but recent changes have led to greater confidence in their ability to see beyond the traditions that built the company. Current CEO is open, frank, and responsive.
cons: The same culture that attracted me to Intel and continues to motivate me can be somewhat stifling. Same as in other large corporations, there are head-scratching moments in the trenches, but most of the time, the logic behind the decisions is eventually visible. A overutilitarian view of the world can lead to feelings of time crunching, but the opportunity for creative work will depend on the individual's outlook and tolerance for Risk Taking. Last, it is a culture in transition, so there can be some dissonance.

review_title: Great place to build a career
pros: Intel is at the heart of high-tech.  When you work there, you know what's coming in many different markets and understand a vision that isn't well communicated elsewhere.  The technology Intel delivers is amazing--almost miraculous.  Being part of that effort is cool!  The best thing about Intel are the brilliant people you'll work with.  You can truly build a great career at Intel doing just about anything you're interested in and qualified for.
cons: The annual review process is terrible and antiquated.  Intel is a huge, slow moving company.  It takes forever for reorganizations to occur and then to become effective.  They pay around the 60th percentile for similar sized tech companies--better than average, but not great.  Raises are hard to come by and work hours are long. While Intel talks a lot about being transparent, many times it is clear you're not getting the real story from executives.  Perhaps the biggest downside to working at Intel is that the technology is aging and Moore's law is clearly coming to an end.  This means it is becoming more and more difficult for them to maintain a competitive advantage.

job_title: Senior Principal Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Salary and benefits are good there
cons: The work life balance is totally out of wack

review_title: Working for Intel..... good or bad decision?? evaluation after 2 years working at Intel.
job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Hillsboro, OR
pros: One of the best reasons of working for Intel Finance is that they have a rotation program that actually allows to switch jobs every 18 months, this is great for you to learn new things and acquire new skills, they also have a management training program for people who want to pursue a career as a manager.  Diversity is great at Intel, lots of networking opportunities, also if you would if you are considering a career change you can do it within the company since there are lots of opportunities in different areas such as Finance,Marketing,HR, Engineering etc.
cons: I think the downside is the worklife balance, the workload is sometimes too much and having a laptop implies that you can take you work home, sometimes managers expect you to be online 24/7; the Intel culture can be to aggressive some times since they are always challenging you and managers a rude most of the time.

job_title: Graduate Intern Technical in Folsom, CA
pros: There are lots of perks. I'm told they didn't do these for a long time, but just started again recently.  Drawings for tickets to local events.  They rented out Dave and Busters for a couple days and provided free food, games, etc.  Benefits are pretty good.  The company itself is really putting effort  into making employees happy at work.
cons: However, the quality of your job really depends on the group you are in, your manager, and the work you are doing. The company encourages movement and job changes every 2 years, but managers are another story.  My manager, thankfully, is very focused on career development and opportunities for me, but I've heard of others who have no interest in that sort of thing.  My advice, find something you love and set up time with people who do it to get advice on how to transition into that field. A lot of people work long hours, but that is there own fault.  They should just STOP working long hours and stop making promises to deliver on things they can't.

job_title: Process Engineer in Rio Rancho, NM
pros: Relatively stable company with healthy profit margins.  8 weeks bonding leave and 4 weeks vacation.  Jefferson and Blaha have both been very outspoken encouraging safety and safe practices.
cons: Lots of red tape, wasted time compiling reports no one looks at, and bureaucracy.  Due to all the rules, employees frequently get put in impossible situations that seem to encourage/reward employees that break/bend the rules.  If you break a rule and there isn't a fallout, you made a good risk decision and took ownership of a difficult problem.  Management pretends not to notice the fact that a policy wasn't followed.  If the risk doesn't work out, you don't have the support of management who can simply say their employee broke rule X and will get coaching.

review_title: Intel is a great place for personal career growth if one can survive the company's environment.
job_title: Senior Program Manager in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Very good benefits; excellent opportunties to work on world changing technologies; good support of work-life balance; excellent community involvement/corporate giving; excellent opportunities for personal professional growth; ability to often work from home; strong supporter of diversity; corporate aircraft travel amongst major sites.
cons: Performance based on a forced bell curve distribution; formerly strong salaries are now lacking in the marketplace; high stress environment; middle management varies widely in competency; accountability for corporate mis-steps is not fully addressed to senior management as layoffs are directed at those who had least responsibility for problems; politics can often circumvent proper decision making; general work force often using old technologies due to company's very conservative approach to spending; decision making is often very beuracratic.

review_title: Very good upper management (GM level and above); but the lower level ????
pros:
Fantastic work culture
Very good support from top management but again the middle layer most of the times would eat you up
Some best of the brains
Abundant learning opportunity if one really wants to learn
If you can reach to a person of vision; he/she will encourage you like anything
Extremely good work life balance (sometime spoiled by your manager)
Overall one of the best companies to work for
cons:
Insecured middle and first level managers; compete with their own employees
Negatinve attitude of some (not all) first level managers in solving issues; target person instead of problem
High ego level of first and second level mangers would make you feel as if they are paying you from their pocket
Unnecessary level of hierarchy 
You polish his/her boot; you are great
Don't be a good samaritan, nor an employee of vision - you will get sucked
Poor performance management - they seriously need to think on it 
Punish the performance is sometime motto - beware of performing beyond your manager or even higher :)

review_title: They want to get rid of people--women esp--- they like to scare you to quit on your own so they don't have to lay you of
pros: Use to be GREAT place to work..they paid for some people's education. Stock plan, vacations, 401K, sabbacticals, these are FABULOUS PERKS.
cons: They ONLY hire /want people with College Degrees!  Steve Jobs and Bill Gates did not graduate college!!  I worked at Intel for over 20 years, they turned down my education request forms saying I was technical enough.  I and many of us are having a difficult time finding work...Intel USED to look good on a resume.  I am learning to write code.

review_title: Not a good place to work right now
pros: Compensation is fair and they offer good perks, e.g. after 7 years of work you get an 8 week sabbatical. The company provides employees services within campus, e.g. onsite dental and vision clinics, onsite bank. Most of the employees I worked with were hard working and really wanted the company to succeed.
cons: Now is not a good time to work for Intel. With the decline of PC sales the company is trying to find it's next product and will go through a series of reorganizations to get there. There was a major restructuring that began in April 2016 and is expected to go until end of 2016-early 2017. Impact included involuntary layoff, early retirement and voluntary separation buyouts, site closures, project cancellations, and departmental efficiency cuts.  Those left behind are fearful for their own futures and scrambling to get work done that used to be filled by co-workers who left. There is a lot of distrust with current management which makes the environment toxic. The company used to enable their employees, now it is a company that manages by fear.

job_title: Graphics Software Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Chip giant, lots of potential.
cons: Horrible managers, overwhelming processes, no team work.

review_title: Intel, good learning experience but don't count on having a life.
pros: the chance to work for a technology market leader, brand recognition, international travel opportunities, incredible internal resources.
cons: very very political, your boss better love you or you will be the first to go. Who can suck up the best ends up staying there longer. There are major differences between "field sales" and working in the "factory" which is referred to as a "cesspool". Intel is a very "what have you done for me lately" place. Not even an "exceeds expectations" on your last Focal review will prevent you from being laid off. If you are in the wrong place, wrong division at the wrong time you can lose your job without any advance warning. But you can be an average or below average performing employee in the right division (cpu or silicon related) and can skate by for years under the radar.

review_title: Doesn't recognize the opportunity to showcase their products with their IT organization.
pros: The benefits package is pretty good. The atmosphere is fairly laid back. Most of the individual contributors are very smart people. And nowadays Intel is making products to really be proud of again.
cons: Corporate management doesn't seem to have a clear direction. There are too many middle managers. Reorgs seem to just be shuffling the same people around. There are few new people bubbling up from the ranks. Those anagers often act as if saving money is more important than employee morale or product quality (I speak of internal software here - the chips are well tested). There are frequent (it seems like perpetual now) reorgs for just reorgs sake - the senior management gets bonuses for making changes, not the result of those changes.

review_title: Great place to work...if you are part of the good ol boys club
pros: Good pay and benefits.  Relatively laid back environment.  Coworkers are good to work with.
cons: Lack of communication, lack of competance of management.  Management tends to be reactive, rather than proactive.  They claim that they promote a work/life balance, but then require that you complete training and meetings on your off days without compensating for it and also to complete projects that more often than not require you to work on your days off.  Treat all employees fairly.  Don't say you can't do something, then allow a select few to get away with it.  Tends to have a "good ol' boys club" and if you aren't part of it, good luck getting promoted.

review_title: Great place to work...if you are part of the good ol boys club
pros: Good pay and benefits.  Relatively laid back environment.  Coworkers are good to work with.
cons: Lack of communication, lack of competance of management.  Management tends to be reactive, rather than proactive.  They claim that they promote a work/life balance, but then require that you complete training and meetings on your off days without compensating for it and also to complete projects that more often than not require you to work on your days off.  Treat all employees fairly.  Don't say you can't do something, then allow a select few to get away with it.  Tends to have a "good ol' boys club" and if you aren't part of it, good luck getting promoted.

pros: In Intel Finance employees have the ability to rotate jobs every 18-24 months.  Typically upon rotation employees are eligible for promotion to the next grade level.  Another plus is the bonus's throughout the year and stock programs which provide at least a 15% return on a 6 month invesment.  In addition, most managers allow employees to work remotely 1-2 days a week and are really understanding when it comes to taking off work or working off hours if you need to.
cons: Reorganizations run your life a lot of the time and many don't make sense.  I expect every 6 months my roles and responsibilities will change.  Management at Intel is either really good or really bad, and if you get stuck with the really bad it could affect not only your career development opportunities but yearly raises as well.  Typically always a little uncertain about layoffs no matter what group you're in, downside of the rotation program is that employees sometimes feel pressured to move on even if they prefer not to.

review_title: Steady work and Steady Pay Fabulous Benefits
pros:
Pay is very competitive to what I was offered elsewhere and Hillsboro is low cost for high tech areas.
Intel hires great people. I have been amazed at the level of talent and how well people work together. I have had a lot of jobs and there were always people that were the slack of the team.
Flexible schedule. I leave all the time midday for appointment (doctors, kids, etc.) and work from home at times.
Big company with thousands of jobs.
cons:
The on-call is tough. This is a FAB that never shutsdown and needs constant attention. The on call is good that right now I'm on a five week rotation so one week on 4 weeks off. 
You are not here to save the world and create the next big thing. You are in manufacturing and fix small problems that are part of the whole. Big world view type problems are handled much higher up.

job_title: Senior Electrical Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: It's a large company with lots of resources.  Good career advancement potential.  You may be lucky and wind up with a good manager. The pay per year may be pretty good.
cons: On the other hand, the pay per hour might not be.  In many groups, they work you to death.  Intel could be a good company to work for if you're young, energetic, compliant, not married (marriage councilors make a lot of money off of Intel employees), and you don't have a life or are willing to give up one.  Be prepared to stay chained to your phone and laptop, even on vacation.  The main thing is that your individual experience at Intel is almost completely up to the manager you happen to get.  In 11 years, I've had both good and horrible managers. The problem with that is that HR policies and practices almost always favor the manager - even really bad ones.  That's a systemic problem, and why I can't recommend working there.

review_title: High stress, long hours: Module Engineer, Process Engineer
job_title: Senior Packaging R&D Engineer in Chandler, AZ
pros:
pay and benefits are above average than what I see in the market place
Lots of chances to prove yourself, lots of smart people to learn from.
I enjoy creating a process and building microprocessors. 
I feel pride in my work
cons:
I believe that having to work 50-70 hours every week is not sustainable. 
There are so many parts of the Sr. Packaging R&D Engineering role it is very difficult to get everything done on time. This title is also called process engineer and Module Engineer.
Have higher ups that like to add stress to the system, verbally put down engineers that are doing the work for them...   Seriously, this is a soft skill that goes so far. Just be nice and helpful to the engineers that are actually doing the work that the managers are delegating. don't put us down, especially in meetings in front of our peers and peers in different groups - I don't know why I have to say this...

pros: No pressure to do anything
cons: Drag corpses around at work

pros: Some good managers but fewer compared to the poor managers.
cons: Tons of poor behavior in the work place.  This is apparently the norm for PTD culture.

review_title: Intel Bangalore not an organization if you are ambitious/ have a non Tech, non Sales Background
pros:
1. Excellent pay package
2. You get to work on products that makes a difference; feeling of accomplishment is great
3. Work with best possible brains in the industry
4. Will get great negotiating power to work with the rest of the Ecosystem
cons:
1. NOT A PLACE TO BE IN if you are NOT into Sales/ Tech work
2. India Leadership is myopic; they take what comes their way
3. Management is clueless and what I have seen is that they don't have a great say in Strategic Initiatives
4. Long working hours, at times thankless jobs
5. Too many unnecessary reviews, management updates with no concrete outcome. Mostly, its a factor of time and stop when Management has enough
6. Learning opportunities far and few. Very little is done for career progression

Some of the Cons are related to India Management and may NOT be necessarily true in US/ elsewhere.

review_title: Poor Management, Beauracracy, Harrasment and Diversity issues
pros: Severance, Sabbatical, Medical, 401K, ESPP
cons:
Constant change in management that doesn't address the real issues, Harassment  is HR's least worry and culture is toxic - if you are a leader, you can lie, cheat, mistreat others as long as you are bringing in quarterly results. Employee loyalty is inspired by constant comparison of "them" (AMD, Nvidia, ARM, TSMC) vs. "us" with little/no accountability on continuous bad decision making. A lot of theatrical performance by leaders and it's surprising how little time is spent on personally getting to know their employees- needs, desires and aspirations. Human resource organization is a joke, they should be called "resources" since the "human" qualities such as empathy is missing. After hiring, no proactive conversation or coaching for diversity candidates - no wonder they leave in few years.  It's alarming the lack of diversity in senior leadership positions. If you are a women and a senior leader, it's highly likely that you'll leave tired of the beauracracy and lack of growth opportunities.It's all about who knows who to get ahead and chances are slim without an executive sponsorship.  One free fruit a day (you are only allowed one per the sign next to it), free coffee and soft drinks (caffeine and sugar is good for performance), "limited choice and average" food in exchange of full price. 

If you want to earn decent money (incom)

job_title: Failure Analysis Engineer in Folsom, CA
pros: work and life balance is good
cons: no innovation. Managements act as government employee

pros: Big canteen but is always full of people
cons: no seats in canteen look above

review_title: No longer a "great place to work'
pros: Intel offers a good salary and benefits however it isn't very fair in annual compensation increases.  the technology is 1st class and it is rewarding to work with equipment that is at the cutting edge.  It would be nice to increase our efficiency with that technology however CE stands in the way.
cons: When I started with Intel in 1997 it was a GREAT company to work for.  Today however, Managers are micromanaged which results in a very stressed and unproductive environment.    There is a very vibrant 'good old boy' network within the management structure which is not healthy.   This use to be a very proactive company and is now a very reactive company. Evidence is a poorly structured and performance 'down sizing' in May of 2009.   Hundreds of employees lost their jobs the same quarter that they announce billions of dollar profits and then we are looking to hire new employees within the next 6-12 months.  Watching your back and walking on eggs is common.

review_title: New marketing organization creating caustic environment for experienced talent
pros: work-life balance. a lot of employees make a career out of working at Intel. total comp is good, but it's a confusing equation of low base pay, geo differential for bay area, largely corporate bonuses, and RSUs
cons: limited opportunity for career advancement.  traditionally the  company encourages lateral movement every 2 years, but upward advancement is difficult. the culture of the corporate marketing organization has become rather negative since the new CMO joined.  there is a big push for all job opportunities within corporate marketing to be filled by external candidates; this makes growth for current marketing folks impossible. you are simply not considered even though you have the appropriate skills and expereince for the role. as a result many talented marketers have left or are actively looking to leave the company and organization

review_title: Was a great company, now searching for its mission
pros: The compensation plan is good. It recognizes contribution, not efforts. That does drive a dynamic around work-life balance (or more accurately, imbalance). That isn't a complaint, it's just an honest statement.
cons:
Bureaucracy. I joined Intel in the late-80's and it was a real kick in the pants! Need something to happen? You own it. You were expected to accomplish what you needed to. Over the years, and very noticeably since 2010, decisions that were formerly mine to make (as a Director) needed "review" by our business unit VP. And it wasn't just me. That same VP complained about the velocity of the company not being where it needed to be. Um, here's a mirror Ms. VP!

Career opportunities aren't what they once were. Intel is in a contraction phase as it continues to struggle whether it has a place in the handheld market (and if so, what...).

review_title: Great place to work, when growing
job_title: Marketing Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Intel is a great place to work because of its global scale, deep and knowledgeable employees and strong culture.  Over a long career, I was able to live and work around the world and developed long lasting relationships with fellow employees.  There are many smart people and good managers at Intel.  If you find yourself working for one of them you will learn a lot and have many opportunities to grow.
cons: When growth is slow or even modest, marketing takes a good share of the immediate financial cuts and there can be a lack of clarity or competing priorities.  Too many decisions need to go all the way to the top which shows a lack of trust in staff's abilities and adds many layers of bureaucracy while at the same time contradicts management's desire for shorter cycle times.  Very few chances to move up given the long tenure of middle to senior managers.

review_title: Horrible if looking to grow your career
job_title: Senior Design Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros:
For most parts in design teams (front end chip design), great work-life balance. I loved the gym classes offered on class.
If work is simply a means to earn money for you, Intel may actually be an amazing place to work.
cons:
Slow mobility even for top performers, unless female or under-represented minority. Bureaucracy stunts career growth, making it a lose-lose situation for someone wanting to grow his/her career. Work hard to grow career? No *quantitative* (i.e. promo/$$) reward. Go at Intel's pace? No career growth.

If Intel at least paid competitively with other top-tier companies (like Apple/~Nvidia), then working hard wouldn't feel as bad. But unfortunately, they "compete" with HP, Dell, Huawei, etc. Especially in Bay Area, where salary variance is high, Intel seems to have just given up in providing competitive pay.

review_title: Challenging, but the right kind of challenging
job_title: Senior Technical Writer in Portland, OR
pros: The near-infinite complexity of the product itself and the scale of the organization make for a highly challenging workplace. Fortunately, the managers and engineers I've worked with are smart, knowledgeable, and driven by a sincere desire to make cool products. Very few managers are ego-driven overachievers, and staff across the organization are approachable and helpful. Also, the commitment to diversity and inclusion is palpable, and is driven by the highest levels of the organization. As a result, project teams and cafeterias look like the United Nations General Assembly (if the U.N. had hipsters with tattoos and piercings), and the glue that holds it all together is the desire to do good work. It probably helps that the competition for market share is fiercer than it has been in a long time.
cons: Sometimes it's hard to work in such a large organization. Sometimes the complexity of it all is hard to deal with. It's always hard to see worthwhile initiatives and innovative products not quite make it into reality.

pros: smart and hard working people
cons: long working hours and not much visibility on the project

review_title: All over the map, but happy right now
pros: The people tend to be brilliant, funny, and kinder than most. Sure, there are some who aren't pulling their weight, but in many cases it's because they're in the wrong position or aren't being challenged. Intel hires well. In some roles, it's easy to move to something new, and the change can be refreshing.
cons: Inconsistency abounds. If your manager is good and supports your career growth and personal life, it can be a great place to be. If your manager isn't as supportive, it can be hell, especially when promotions are few and lateral moves are hard to come by. Great Development Opportunity Tool (DOT) - if you're allowed to use it. I have friends who are desperate for new challenges, who have DOT hiring managers who want to bring them in to work on something - and they've been denied permission to take it on. They're stuck and miserable.

review_title: Great company with great people and products
pros: Intel pays a competitive wage, offers competitive benefits and is filled with great, intelligent, dedicated people. Top level management is excellent. The 8-week paid sabbatical for all employees for each 7 years of service is wonderful.
cons: Like any large company, there is some incompetence, negligence and corruption in small pockets throughout the company. It exists among individual contributors and first line and middle management. In my experience, Human Resources has mostly not been supportive of individual employees in disputes with management. I witnessed about 10 HR investigations in 15 years and don't recall a single one ending in favor of the employee though several of them should have. HR investigations are not thorough or objective and they are not forthcoming with employees about how the investigation process works even when asked direct questions.

review_title: Great company with great people and products
pros: Intel pays a competitive wage, offers competitive benefits and is filled with great, intelligent, dedicated people. Top level management is excellent. The 8-week paid sabbatical for all employees for each 7 years of service is wonderful.
cons: Like any large company, there is some incompetence, negligence and corruption in small pockets throughout the company. It exists among individual contributors and first line and middle management. In my experience, Human Resources has mostly not been supportive of individual employees in disputes with management. I witnessed about 10 HR investigations in 15 years and don't recall a single one ending in favor of the employee though several of them should have. HR investigations are not thorough or objective and they are not forthcoming with employees about how the investigation process works even when asked direct questions.

pros: You will always be surrounded with the smartest people.  Great benefits at a great cost, Everyone is accepted (Corporate America but casual and laid back).  Free fruit and beverages for employees, subsidized onsite cafeterias with various food genres, onsite gym, vision, doctor, etc.
cons:
There are some old-school people here who complain a lot because (fill in the blank) isn't like it used to be.    Funny how they want the perks of the 60s but not the pay they had.  ??

Kind of TOO MUCH emphasis on diversity like we feel we need to brag about it by boasting numbers all of the time.

Red tape with some things - normal amounts for a corporation.

As a whole, they are against working from home for office workers but won't exactly come out and say that.

review_title: iCDG (modem) group review in San Diego
job_title: Software Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros:
- Great company with 20% work remotely perk and flexible vacation days up to 4 weeks/yr. 
- Lucky enough to have some flexible and good managers.
cons:
- Intel HR has been promoting diversity, diversity, and diversity. But, seriously, first day I came to office, I was lost. I though I was working in Bangalore office, not San Diego.  
The issue with this is that people often speak their own language at work, which is according to HR is unlawful.  And, how can people who don't belong to this ethnic group can be sure that they are not discriminated at performance review?
This flaw is probably causing failures in this BU. 
- As a company, Intel always prefers to hire in India instead of other places. Seriously, there are talents there and cheap cost. But, if you play cheap, you will get bad result. It is happening now. You can't beat deliver tech as complex as 5G if you play cheap. You get what you paid for and costing employees their jobs.

review_title: Used to be great place to work......
job_title: Senior IT Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros:
Pay is excellent and the sabbatical leave (US) is unbeatable.
Cool technology!
Opportunity to work on projects that have global impact.
Opportunity to work in a variety of locations around the globe.
cons:
Training opportunities within IT are trending downward
IT is considered a cost of doing business and is always under extreme pressure to be reduced
Many, many reorganizations that make continuity and follow through difficult to impossible
Senior IT Management does not inspire or demonstrate real leadership
Work/Life balance isn't

review_title: It's A Manufacturing Company First & Foremost
job_title: Senior Something Unspecific in Chandler, AZ
pros:
- Seems to have adopted some of Silicon Valley's best cultural traits like valuing employees, data-driven decisions, and aligning on problem statements
- Benefits & quarterly cash bonuses are nice, as are quarterly, Intel-funded employee bonding sessions
- Solid severance packages
- Every site is different (Silicon Valley vs Chandler vs Hillsboro vs Dalian vs Penang, etc.) and you can move between them if you don't like where you are
cons:
- It's a manufacturing company FIRST, tech company distant 2nd
- Moore's Law is a cult-like chant inadvertently used to blind senior leadership (e.g., BK) to disruption
- Samsung & TSMC can (and probably will) break the company's mfg scale advantage
- The company is *WAY* behind in AI (Artificial Intelligence) / ML (machine learning) / MV (machine vision) and may never be able to catch NVidia, despite hopping into bed with AMD
- Rapid career advancement is impossible if you didn't come up through manufacturing (FSM) or get recruited out of a top 7 MBA program
- Layoffs happen pretty frequently

review_title: Great potential if note stifled by bureaucracy; stay around for the insurance.
pros: Resources (e.g. equipment, expertise) are widely available.  The chance to make a difference in the PC industry is greater here than nearly any other place.  There remain some very smart people, even though many have left either due to incompetent management or lack of ability to cut through the bureaucracy.
cons: Intel has a simply huge extremely bloated bureaucracy.  This results in the inability to make decisions -- either to try something new or to quit doing something old.  As a result, it can be EXTREMELY frustrating to watch.  Many groups have strongly top down management style, usually by people who often have no clue (technical or business-wise).  There are a lot of old-timers who rose in the ranks either from length of being there or from having so many people hired under them.  These people are usually not bright, and usually INCREDIBLY insecure, resulting in political nightmares.  See the book "Losing Faith" (google it) for a good description.

pros: There's a lot of interesting projects going on all the time. If you're the type of person who likes to work on something different every few years, Intel is the place for you. There's plenty of opportunity to learn new things by going from project-to-project.
cons:
Intel does not always have a clear focus on what it wants to do in order to continue growing. Aside from the basics of chip manufacturing, it changes its mind on what to specialize in every 5-10 years. That means that your project that was hot 5 years ago is likely to be scrapped now. Don't get too attached to any one project.

You also have to be careful to be good at many things, or at least show that you can learn quickly. If you are known for being good at only one thing, you run the risk of being let go once your "one thing" is no longer relevant to the latest important projects.

job_title: Senior Process Engineer in Chandler, AZ
pros: Good benefits and pay is good.  Not a bad company to start at but eventually you will out grow it.
cons: No career paths, Focal ends up being event based vs. your actual contributions.   Work life balance really does not exist if you want to stay on the right side of layoffs.  Multiple levels of management with unclear roles and responsibilities.  Also in TMG pretty much only one person in the entire organization makes decisions.  People may not believe it but it is actually true.  I think is is why Intel has lost all it's competitive manufacturing edge.

pros: Hi im working in Intel.
cons: It's presure to working with you

pros: They have a lot of career options with compressed work week schedule which equals more pay and long weekends.  Constant technology improvments is exciting.  Intel takes security and well being of employees very seriously.  Coorparate discounts for many companies.  Open door policy.  If they have good quarters they will give out bonuses bonuses.  I feel like the company is in good hands with the talent they have working there.  Most managers don't micro manage you.  Wokriing in a bunny suit is so much fun!  If you start as a technician there you have two choices, you can take long breaks, relax a lot or you can rapidly move up in job titles.  Most are satisfied with either and both are fun.
cons: Stock never goes up.  I have worked for many managers, most just encouraged me to work, but some of them got in my way.  There are also some higher level managers who are to visionary.

review_title: Intel's core value of "Great Place to Work"
pros: It is a great place to be if you want to do Complex Designs, utilize Leading Edge technology, explore a diversified work environment, have a stake in the company and have opportunity to travel to, or work in, different places around the world
cons: It is not a great place to work if you abhor decision by committee or being forced to climb the corporate ladder.  After the big layoff last year, the work environment has drifted negative with folks wondering as to when the other foot will fall.  The days of being given a short breather to find a new home with-in the company when your position is eliminated are gone.

review_title: Great individual contributors, but currently ossified leadership
pros:
Some of the smartest and driven people you will ever work with,  at the IC level . 
Quite good total compensation.
cons:
Lots of top-down direction from highest management leads to indecision and micromanagement from "leaders." They can't do their job, so they try to do yours.

Dirty/disgusting facilities: At my campus, they stopped cleaning. Spills stay for days to weeks; there are pools of urine and scattered toilet paper in the bathrooms, dust bunnies (size of bunnies) in the stairwells.

High-level management interfering in former meritocracy around promotions. I had my highest performers held back and my lowest performers coddled due to direct intervention by senior management.  The high performers were held back by rules that changed every review cycle; the low performers had personal (ethnic) connections with senior leadership.  This caused inversions in pay/grade versus actual contribution and impact. The "this guy is friends with the VP, so he doesn't have to perform" was not supposed to happen at Intel... oh well.

Current model is to take advantage of driven personalities of Intel engineers by loading more work on them until they break.

review_title: Intel - a great place to work, even if for only average pay
pros:
Intel was great with work/life balance.  In such a big company this probably depends on your department, but in Materials it was excellent.  

I also liked the fact that there was a true "open door" policy where a person could talk to a manager several levels above them without negative backlash.  In my current company if I were to do this my manager would not be happy, but at Intel I was encouraged to set up meetings with my manager's manager.

Intel offers 2 months off with pay every 7 years to all FT employees.  This is not a benefit you can cash in on very often but it is a fantastic benefit when it comes due!
cons: I felt like the pay was only average.  When I started looking at other jobs I felt like I could do better by going outside Intel than by staying.  In the end I left the company and got more than a 20% pay increase.

review_title: Intel - it's not what you think.
pros: The best reasons are the benefits and the time off.
cons:
There are many downsides. The biggest that that we face is having way too much management. We have entire layers of managers that do nothing but manage other managers. But when we have a genuine need for more people in the cleanroom to - you know - actually make the company money, we're met with snide remarks about how we should just work harder and suck it up with the same headcounts. But they'll hire 2 managers for every 1 that leaves the company.

The Pay! The pay and the entire advancement system needs rewritten. When you work for an industry leader, you shouldn't have to take a second job just to make ends meet. But that's just what I, and many of my co-workers and team mates, have to do just to make it.

pros: When I started in 1997 Intel was a data driven company that was in the middle of disrupting the server market, on its way to win 98% share.  The successes and people who drove them in past is the biggest pro for Intel.  There are still many veterans in the company who are smart, savy and driven.
cons: There are 2 main cons.  1) The culture of Intel has degraded over the years from one of the best to way below average.  There is a large amount of bureaucracy/politics that has replace the data-driven decisions of the past with "who you know" decisions today.  This is extremely sub-optimal.  2) Intel is being heavily disrupted by ARM in phones, tablets and now even segments of laptops.  It is only a matter of time before that battle will more to servers, Intel's only "cash cow".  Add to that the fact that the vast majority of CPU design and mfg jobs outside of Intel are in Asia.  So if Intel continues to layoff it's workers due to ongoing ARM disruption you will likely be forced to either switch industries or look for a job overseas.

pros: Salary is great, Salary packet is very transparent (no padding): what you see is what you get. None of that hoax about variable performance pay that is there in other places.
cons: Mindless, repetitive, boring meetings, discussing same thing again and again, from first thing in the morning to very late into the night. Someone always looking over your shoulder (there are even people who tell you how to sit in your chair - No jokes!) Felt I was in some kind of a weird Kafkaesque prison camp. Forced to attend late night meetings 5 days a week, even though I had personal problems. No time left for personal life - which is acceptable if you are doing amazing , exciting work, not for attending silly meetings. I was finally forced to quit because I wouldn't attend daily late night meetings.  Forced to attend "training camps" where you have to memorize the 10 things that make Intel a "Great Place to Work".... Ghastly place to work is a better description. Possibly it was just my department that was like this, or perhaps only Intel India is like this. I can't believe that Intel became the most successful tech co. in the world like this. Salary is great - but this place made me realize salary is not everything.

review_title: politics, no innovation and a career deadend
pros: The pay and benefits are good and it is a good name to have on your resume. It's big and an industry leader.
cons: Obviously being advertised as a big tech company, that's what most see. As an employee in the trenches, you soon realize it is politics, and no innovation (unless you worked there 30 years ago). It's easy to lead when you are 1000 miles ahead due to being a pioneer. However, in technology a 1000 miles can evaporate in 5 years with new ideas and innovations (ask Polaroid and others). The semiconductor industry is limited to a few big companies in a few places. If you can pick another industry, do so. If you are already stuck in it, make your money but start planning an exit (classes, new degree, PhD). Your career choices and places of work in the future depending on field of expertise will be otherwise extremely limited (unless you like moving). Your job depends on the stock price and quarterly reports. This company has tried for 9 years to enter the cell phone/tablet market without success. With all the cash in the bank, only stupidity from upper management can impede such an endeavor.

pros: I was surrounded by people far smarter than I could ever be. Most of the people I ran into were pretty decent folk, trying to do the best they could. In many ways, working at Intel is a bit like working at Ground Zero of what used to be the personal computing revolution. There is history there and one is awed. Intel was (still is) fanatical about tight processes. Read the book by Andy Grove (ex-CEO, now deceased) called "High Output Management".
cons: Big companies lose their way and Intel was no different. It's hard to keep culture when you add thousands upon thousands of employees. Class systems develop. Stupid stuff gets done just because someone with a bigger title -- not a better argument or more vetted data -- won the day. We're talking about billions of dollars of mis-allocated resources and its painfully obvious to everyone but no one dare say anything. Think of it as corporate political correctness. Andy would be appalled.

review_title: Great Place to Work with plenty of opportunities
pros:
*Awesome learning ground
*internal rotation highly encouraged, able to take up new jobs and learn new things
* Great benefits and facilities
cons:
*Brutal performance ranking system. Still stuck in the past utilizing bell-curve ranking system (forced ranking). You can be a star performer and still ranked average.
* Career growth can be slow-linked to above and below point
*Plenty of office politics/favoritism. Not impossible to maneuver but can be difficult depending on your personality or if you're new to work life.
*C&B philosophy which is rather obsolete compared to close competitors. Not to say they pay poorly but certainly can be improved rather than being defensive on it being one of the best.

review_title: Intel - some things are great, some things need work
pros: Intel has great benefits and, depending on what group you are in, give you a lot of flexibility and respect.  I love the "about three weeks of vacation per year" and the fact that no one is tracking my hours.  They care if I get my job done, not if I left fifteen minutes early.  Work can be challenging (in a good way) and I have worked with some of the smartest and most competent people I have ever met.
cons: Those who can't do sometimes wind up managing.  And as a software engineer at a hardware company you are a red haired step child.  Intel knows how to make world class silicon, their processes and techniques are stellar.  But they haven't grasped that software is different, and without software the best silicon in the world is just a really expensive doorstop.

job_title: Senior Marketing Manager in Aloha, OR
pros: You will have lots of different roles and responsibilities
cons: Your role will change all of the time

pros: There are many opportunities for career growth
cons: big company , bureaucracy, bureaucracy mmm

pros: Great place , the best company
cons: Great place no bad things

pros: Great medical Plan and voucher
cons: Not sure maybe it is far from the city

pros: The company Care about the individual
cons: It is a big company that can sometimes move very slow

pros: It was very nice my friend
cons: I dont know anything bad

pros: Good Benefits and very take care of employees
cons: Upper management keep changing from time to time

job_title: Systems Validation Engineer in Chandler, AZ
pros: No significant pros, pretty standard comany with a safe job. Easy to move within but there wont be much growth with internal transfers
cons: Pay is less compared to other similar semiconductor companies

job_title: Soc Design Engineer in Bayan Lepas
pros:
Opportunity for career growth
Salary is above market rate
cons:
Promotion isn't performance-based.
