review_title: Process and equipment engineer in Kiryat Gat
job_title: Process and Equipment Engineer In Kiryat Gat in Qiryat Gat
pros: Good benefits, quarterly bonuses, yearly bonuses, health insurance, overall salary is about 30% higher than what's stated.
cons:
You have to know that you will work overtime every day.
You leave work at 17:00 but you have to continue working at home for roughly 1-3 more hours, and it's already portrayed in the salary, so there's no extra pay.
The factory works 24x7, it means you have to give engineering support around the clock, that means working from home on weekends and even during the night. Yep, wake up and open your computer at 02:00 AM, and then again at 04:00 AM happens. This is what an around the clock factory needs. You are never free of work and you have to be available at the company's provided phone and have your company's provided computer with you when you are the "point of contact duty" - about 1-2 days a week.
There is no pay for driving fare. If you're not using the company's transportation, you pay your own gas expenses. The minibus transportation is awful, they've put seats in commercial trucks and it breaks you back during the ride. Some destinations have buses and they are much more comfortable.
Personal promotion is declared to be about performance, but it is mostly given to "yes men" and the ones who are willing to do whatever it takes...
People are constantly worried about their job, the number 1 private conversation subject for all the years I've been working there was whether there's a big employee layout  soon, or not. Worries makes most people become competitive, this generates "job-security" behaviors.

review_title: Lack of support for out of the box thinking, pay equity is not what it seems, too much cost cutting..
pros: You can find some people with similar passions that are willing to support you and push for positive change.
cons:
Employees are not empowered to make decisions, everything is top down (even when the top doesn’t have the knowledge needed to make the decision) which slows down decision making and can lead to poor decisions. Too much time is spent trying to educate management rather than doing the work to make a positive impact.

Intel promotes their pay equity, but pay equity can only exist when the staff is in the right pay grade. Major complaint is that even when proving you are doing the work of the next grade, or possibly two grades, there are consistent excuses as to why you can’t get a promotion, such as there is a “waiting list” and you’re far down on the list, or due to reorg you’re in a new group and need to prove yourself again (even though your job/goals didn’t change). Most of us who discuss these challenges are women, yet Intel supposedly has achieved pay equity and met their diversity goals. If consistently exceeds isn’t going to be considered, why have it?

Cost cutting has slowed innovation, reduced community initiatives and has dramatically slowed the pace of change.

pros: The pay and benefits are great.  The company has a desire to move into new and exciting markets and catch up to those markets that they have let slip through their fingers.  There is always a new project or team or combination of the two that you may be able to join if you are unhappy.
cons: Most people who work for the company don't understand how to deal with people.  This becomes a significant problem when dealing with new market segments.  Most of the people working at Intel want everything to be broken apart and siloed.  This makes any work surrounding experiences impossible to accomplish.  People at Intel are easy enticed by buzzwords and even more easily enticed by the option to simply purchase a service or software package, rather than have to think for themselves.  The average age of the managerial staff and above set them apart from the demographics that present the most viable future market opportunities.

review_title: Great environment, flexible hours, valuable work, and great benefits/pay!
pros: Since I started working at Intel, my life has changed dramatically. I no longer stress out on Sunday evenings about the thrashing I may or may not receive at work the subsequent week! I look forward to work every day, and even take glances at design issues at home sometimes, not because I have to, mind you, because it crosses my mind as part of my normal day. AKA: something I just enjoy doing. My managers and coworkers are all people that I want to help succeed, and so my work has a feeling of importance to it that helps me excel.
cons: As with any large company, the chain of command and approval for new features and bug fixes is fairly complex. Sometimes it will take a month or more to initiate change, especially with design. However, this can be an advantage, because it gives you plenty of time to change your mind about designs and/or improve your work.

review_title: Will change your life.. !! Amazing company, who actually know how to take care of their employees.
pros:
As my title suggest, it is an awesome company to work for(this is no stereotype compliment to Intel). Believe me. 
1. They have so many things for employees, which will takes weeks for one to understand all of it.
2. One-thing which standout is ' Great work-life balance '. Frankly speaking none say this, you'll eventually realize. 
3. If your in a good project, your work will be extremely challenging and you'll be equally responsible with great visibility. 
4. Pay will definitely be much higher than the industry standard, often you wont be even thinking about it, coz there are so many things happening. 
5. Employees are actually & really proud to say they work for Intel Corp. Lot of old-timers with 20+ years in the firm.
6. Pay, stock options, great managers, relaxed atmosphere, medical insurance for you and your family, great office spaces, etc are the few highlights. And not forgetting to mention the brand. You'll instantly be recognized anywhere, anytime.
cons:
1. After lot of merger, it has been little dynamic. That being said, it doesn't mean they are letting people go, its just that they want employees to be up-to mark with industry and hence you might be shuffled across teams. Which in long run is good for company and employees. 2. They need to find a revolutionary way of integrating their new found Software Security love a.k.a McAfee with the power & experience of other BUs of Intel Corp and vice versa.
3. The firm is an elephant in its own way with decades of history behind them, hence at times you feel things flows little late.

pros:
A relatively stable workplace. Intel also provides a pretty good work-life balance and allows working from home and taking your vacation when you wish. Career-wise, you can always take a new direction inside the company and start with a brand new job without actually starting over.
People are usually very nice and keen to help each other, it is not a very competitive place, in a good way mostly. Additionally, management is accessible, you can talk to anyone.
Intel has recently made its move towards servers and IoT, and also released many of its employees, I believe that this was a smart move.
cons:
The work itself felt very disconnected from the end-product and therefore motivation was low. Creativity is not encouraged, you do your job, you finish it, you go home. The job got quite boring after a while.
Professionally, it feels like a mess, software tools are being used while nobody knows where they came from, it is all patched up and progress is hard to be made. Workflows are usually very unstable.
Culture-wise, Intel is a huge corporate which is trying to meet the lowest common denominator, in such a workplace, that would be a too common and boring denominator. Atmosphere at the office is not much fun.

review_title: Great work life balance, great stepping stone
job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Portland, OR
pros: In finance, you get to rotate every 2 years, so gives you a lot of opportunities to learn something new or be in a different group. Also, you have a big network of other finance peers and mentors, which can help a lot when picking a rotation. Work life balance is also really great. As an analyst (not a manager), usually you work 40-45 hours max.
cons:
1) Bureaucracy - since it's such a big company and there are so many stakeholders to go through, it's super slow to get things moving, which can be quite frustrating. 
2) For finance, there are specific times that you can't take days off (Plan/Close). Usually since it's known somewhat ahead of time, you can plan around it, but sometimes there are just events that you just can't change. 
3) Most of the need for finance jobs are FP&A. Most people only want to do FP&A for the first one or two rotations (as a grade 3 and/or grade 5), and then move on to different functions, like cost, revenue, or product investment. But now they keep raising the grade level so that many of the grade 6 jobs are also FP&A. 
4) Applying for a new job is also not so easy. For example, when they post a job at a grade 5, it can be up-scoped to a 6 or down-scoped to a 3. So if you are a 3 (but supported for a grade 5) applying for this, you might not get the job since they say there are other people already at a grade 5 applying for the role, and they have more experience.

review_title: Clever, ethical company, let down by poor sales teams.
pros: Great engineering company, whose products have been second to none for a long time. Company has high ethical standard and practices them. Very intelligent staff. Most people stay at Intel for more than 10 years.
cons:
No training: not a single day of training for employees on how to work with this massive organisation of 100+ employees, its products or extensive partner network. Managers discourage training by withholding funding.

Everyone has the authority have a say on anything, but no responsibility for the consequences. Expect more and more 'decision makers' to be brought into every meeting and disrupt decision making. Even managers are frustrated by their teams going rogue.

Sales teams are inward facing, spending time in internal meetings than working with customers. Some hoard information to justify their job titles. You are told by the CEO downwards to sell yourself internally and build an internal network if you want to be successful. 

Poor communication structure: emails are ignored, yet you receive 200+ per day. You're required to call a meeting to discuss anything. e.g., I had to present at least 5 forecast meetings every week!

Old-school sales teams that rely on the function-feature of excellent products, or by offering marketing dollars. Not once will a sales person ask what's in it for the customer and sell on value. This is hard to maintain now that Intel faces true competition in mobile, tablet and other sectors. How many Apple products or Android phones run Intel?

Most sales people don't actually sell. They simply influence a customer's decision or latch on to a successful reseller to claim commissions.

review_title: CEO shows true colors, manages employees like factory machines
pros: Still surrounded by a shrinking proportion of smart people making new stuff (sometimes enduring, sometimes doomed).
cons:
BK initiated a blacklist for 1000+ employees in June of 2015.

Surprised, shocked, disheartened. For a company earning billions in Net Profits even despite the constant cry-wolf of "we need to tighten our belts, we're in trouble, we need to deliver more 'value' to 'shareholders' (who I feel are just an artificial and convenient proxy for "I want to do something tough but I don't want to accept responsibility for it, so I'll blame a crowd of nameless, impossible-to-identify people who probably aren't even rattling the cage any harder than any other company").

It made me sick of the corporate doublespeak and feeling of being treated like cattle who (as long as you don't speak the truth in front of them) will never actually understand what's going on around them until the bolt crosses their skull directly.

Hearing all the individual stories from colleagues (of people hit by this death-by-spreadsheet action) makes me glad I'm no longer part of Intel - decided to move after years of ignoring my own gut sense that Intel has terminal cancer and will never shake off its 40 years of fossilized "culture" (which is just a polite way of saying "habit" and "bullying" in one palatable syllable) and may never turn into an organization that values risk-taking, actions-over-ass-covering and investing in the long-term of its people resources.

review_title: Good company, lots of opportunities, average pay, bad middle management, constant state of flux.
pros: There are lots of opportunities to learn new skills and challenge yourself. There are also a lot of smart people to learn from and coworkers are generally very generous with knowledge. Risk taking & outside of the box thinking are both valued & encouraged, but admittedly only so much. If you are unhappy with you're job or simply looking for a new challenge, there are always plenty of jobs around the country & world to transfer to. Infact you are encouraged to change jobs every 3 to 5 years. Pay is above average for lower end jobs (mail room, manufacturing assemblers, building maintenance, etc) as well as for higher end jobs (principal engineers, business unit managers, etc). For those of us in the middle, the pay is average or sometimes below average.
cons: The two biggest cons are; 1) constant threat of layoffs due to structure & efficiency gains, 2) middle management is clueless. I worked in one team for 8 years, during that time we had; 4 restructurings, split 2 times, merged 2 times...all those lead to 5 rounds of layoffs. The constant change in the charter of the group, type of work, and threat of losing your job is not good for moral. Add to that the fact middle management is there because they are not quslified to do the work, but they are the one doing your yealy review. it makes it very difficult to get promotions.

job_title: Finance Analyst in San Jose, CA
pros:
- Pay is decent for the area. 
- Finance has a rotation program which lets you experience different business units, groups,and job functions.
- Lots of perks (gym, free soda, company planes that fly between campuses)
- In general the people are really smart, hard working and fun to be around
cons:
- Middle management is a dead layer. Lots of people promoted because they were great individual contributors, but are really poor people managers. Almost all promotions come from within, which is great for morale but also means that you never get any new blood with experience managing at other companies.
- Lots of management layers, so decision making is slow, and by the time something gets up to the top decision makers things often fall apart and create huge fire drills to get things done on time.
- Work life balance can be non-existent depending on your manager. There tends to be a lot of emphasis that you can work "smarter" but they really just mean get the work done, regardless of what you have to do. The good managers help folks prioritize and kill low value projects, the bad ones just expect you to get it done and eventually you'll rotate anyway.
- Career advancement past a certain point is extremely difficult and slow.
- Culture can be super competitive and cut-throat.
- Lot

job_title: Senior Yield Engineer in Chandler, AZ
pros:
Lots of really smart and hardworking front line people.
The health insurance options are hard to beat.
cons:
If you're in manufacturing you won't be innovating, you'll be replicating.
No thinking is involved in most jobs.  I could have done my senior engineering job right after I got out of the 3rd grade.
The middle management is riddled with sociopaths that make work miserable. 
Intel leads from the back seat.  They don't innovate or drive industry change.  They wait for someone else to make the first move and then dump tons of money to chase after other company's disruptions.
You will constantly hear about people being performance managed.  Its Intel's way to push people out of the company and as soon as they are done with one person they move to the next person that isn't part of their agenda.  If you're there long enough it will eventually be you.

job_title: Senior Engineering Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Intel is like many companies in one. During my time, I was able to gain experience across EDA, Logic Design, Verification, Physical Design, Software Optimization at Compiler Lever among other things. For the most part, I was fortunate to have worked with some of the sharpest people in the Industry. Moving from one business unit to another was not difficult and one could pursue opportunities based on interest.
cons: Even though I personally did not suffer too much from performance management related issues, I was always discouraged by the way performance management was done at Intel. Towards the latter end of my career, I myself was forced to follow some of the direction even though I always felt disgusted. Meritocracy it seems was not really rewarded and it always seemed that the laggards somehow were better at surviving. While I have utmost respect for technically competent people, men or women, in the name of diversity, I saw some of the women being given leadership opportunities even though they did not deserve it - in some cases, their feedback was sub par but since they were connected to upper management, they kept getting promoted. In the last 5-7 years especially, decision making had significantly deteriorated across some BU but some of these keep surviving

review_title: Great opportunity to work on cutting edge technology but politics and stealing credit is becoming more common.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Flexible timings, opportunity to work on cutting edge technology, smart coworkers, great technical career track, relatively high freedom to innovate and drive your ideas.
cons: Beauracracy and politics is taking center stage. Senior leaders (especially technical leaders) are highly political and will try to take credit for things you have done. The focal process is highly focussed on past year and does not take into account the grade level you are working at. If you group changes or the manager changes, you can be pretty sure that you have lost your promotion chance that year, even if you worked really hard and produced outstanding results. You are then left hoping that you get a similar opportunity to perform next year and there are no org changes in the middle of the year (which by the way happens quite often in Intel) . Software is still treated as step child. Their is no management conviction on software projects and they keep shutting them down prematurely or move them to low cost geos where they get delayed and finally they shut it down. The strategy/focus changes every six months as management has no clue about the market or confidence in their ability to carry forward the project.

review_title: Management is everything here, good, bad, or ugly.
pros: Assuming you have a good manager, work is rewarding, teams are excellent, there is plenty of fun to be had, though in measure with the grinding to get a product out.  The company is spinning up an entirely new division (phones and tablets).  Free fruit and drinks in the cafe (not food too :( ).  There is a board game geek group that has game nights, you can see games at lunch.  Overall an enjoyable atmosphere.  There are a couple game rooms spread across the FM campus, shuffleboard, Foosball, pool tables, Wii's...
cons:
If you have a crap manager it is time to move.  If you don't enjoy working here then you have a crap manager.  Simple as that.  It may not be your immediate manager, but somewhere close is crap.  Identify the crap and move to another group/team/whatever to get out from under the crap.
I've see people complain about being worked to death... Put your foot down and quote Paul about work life balance.  If you still have issues, switch teams.

pros: High caliber of talented individuals, pretty good pay and benefits, great work life balance programs
cons: Unqualified managers and management teams, management playing favorites in focal, difficult to move into new jobs, empire building for certain managers

review_title: Working at Intel is an extremely stimulating place to work and gives you excellent opportunities for advancement.
job_title: Senior Strategic Marketing Manager in Hillsboro, TX
pros: If you like to be on the cutting edge of technology and work with the brightest people around then you will have a great experience. It is important that you are comfortable in an environment that requires you to be independent and chart your own career path. If you are then there are ample opportunities to lead and work on great projects and teams. Work-life balance is pretty good compared to many other tech companies but does require excellence and what comes with it which is hard work and sometimes long hours. Total compensation is very good overall.
cons: While I love the concept of 'constructive confrontation' it can be taken too far. The culture requires nay sayers and there are times when it is not appropriate. However, when you miss major changes in the market the way Intel has it is pretty important to be always paranoid. The shifts in the market also bring on constant divisional changes and changes in teams which can be frustrating as you don't always get the time to get traction on a new initiative when things shift to the new latest trend and all resources go with it. In terms of promotions the ranking and rating system is flawed which can seriously hold up your opportunities. Also, being a manager does not get you any credit at performance review time.

pros: A huge company -- still lots of career opportunities, people to learn and stuff to do.  It still has plenty of inertia to sustain itself for many years to come.
cons:
It's no longer engineering or product company, it's play the game by the rules company. No matter where do you work, in the end the only thing that is matter is what kind of political game you play. It's huge company, with 100000+ people, so it is bound to have some people doing only noise while others do work. But in years that I was there it went from 80/20 to 50/50 workers/noisers ratio. The slogans of Intel now are only what they are - slogans, no meanings. And no feedback is requested. It is not that management does not tolerate critique -- it is completely ignores it. You can yell your head out, and then everyone will continue the day.
And finally, the feeling in down below that big brass have no more clue than anyone else, and just keep playing the game all the same, reshuffling thousands of people, letting hundreds go, buying companies for milliards to shut them down... it feels like Titanic.

review_title: I survived at Intel for 8 years. But left the company Oct. 2010
pros:
Intel is considered to be CSR (corporate social responsibility) oriented company. Seemingly it takes a good care of it's employees in terms of perks and professional development. 

There are however a lot of complaints being heard about the quality of middle management... incompetent managers, etc.
cons: Intel's Focal process is riddled with flaws. Case in point: the requirement to collect 360 feedback from your peers (~7+). Providing feedback on your manager a different matter as there is often no other method to obtain honest opinion on management's performance. But there is an obvious conflict of interest when the very same people who are in your ranking group are asked to provide 360 feedback. It is often very easy to put 2&2 together and pinpoint the source of negative comments. For instance, I remember going way beyond the call of duty helping someone who made some unfair comments.

job_title: Engineer Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Still pockets of technical excellence and brilliance. Still has lot of money making products. Teams working on every stack from virtual reality and machine learning to physics and manufacturing. A mini industry in itself. Benefits are pretty good.
cons:
Current bad management will run it to the ground. Bad/No strategy is killing the company fast. 
Every group has its own hiring policy, so many bad engineers tend to get hired due to sloppy interviews (bad hires hire other bad hires). Due to good benefits, bad people dont leave, while good get frustrated and leave. Messed up diversity hiring, messed up layoffs, messed up closing of sites, projects, messed up reorgs etc.

pros: Benefits are great, always improving services / facilities for employees, work life balance (depends), great to have the name in resume, work from home, my team works great together
cons:
Depending on which team, work life balance isn't great (previous team). 9-5 isn't 9-5 and holidays or taking annual leave doesn't feel like a holiday because you still get call to work. Even if you don't pick up, somehow, you get contacted through other means.
Salary is good but the other benefits compensate for a good overall 'salary' package. 
Some groups tend to escalate matters directly to the next-next (and next) level managers before understanding the matter at hand. It only waste productivity because, then, every line manager gets involved for one matter. 
Career development can be stagnant because opportunities within HR are either limited or for selected.

review_title: Great place to be worked into the ground until you give up and just collect a check
pros: There are a lot of options to move to different departments across a wide variety of different careers without leaving a single company.
cons:
Working as a salaried employee in a manufacturing role is just soul crushing.  The expectation of being on call (and you will be called non-stop)  24x7 for years on end with no compensation lies ahead if you choose this career path.  

The only other area of concern is the inability to do what is right.  There is an umbrella of upper middle managers at the non-development sites that are neither technical or leaders.  It has created a culture of managing metrics not matter how ridiculous and pointless the metric.  As long as the daily report is green then expect an e-mail with a dancing Snoopy saying "great work" and if it is red a frowning emoji saying "there's opportunity".  You spend your day making sure unfavorable data is deleted or subverted so the management chain through the emoji master doesn't freak out.

review_title: Some great people, great benefits, but with some big-corp downsides.
pros: The compensation and benefits seem competitive for this area.  There are lots of jobs you can change to without leaving the company if you're in software, finance, etc. if you want to try something else.  Lots of brilliant people to work with.
cons: It's a huge corporation.  Mid-upper management can be out of touch with things like just how much is wasted on running a team of engineers split across a ridiculous time zone difference, for instance.  It's hard to make a difference in teams or organizations this huge.  Politics and other nastiness can negate any major contribution you make.  There are rumblings of unqualified candidates being hired because of diversity initiatives, and other unfairness.  They claim to promote work/life balance, but in practice you often can't do that and also make promotions / earn good reviews.  There seems to be a line above which you can't be fired or dinged for utter failure.  If you're below that line, look out when times get tough.

review_title: The people! Diverse, intelligent, opinionated and extremely knowledgeable. If
pros:
The people! Diverse, intelligent, opinionated and extremely knowledgeable. If you want to be surrounded by people that actually *know* every single thing about computers and software, there's no other place

Intel has many worlds inside itself. If you change from one team to another, is like changing from one company to another, everything is totally different. So if you're bored with one aspect of technology, change to a different group and learn about other stuff without leaving company.

The benefits are mostly great (see exceptions at the list of downsides), in special the medical benefits.

It is inspiring to work in products that are used by millions (and in some cases billions) of people.
cons:
There's no transparency on how people's performance are reviewed, the only clear thing is that it is a popularity contest where the management friends are rewarded and everyone else hang on tight because of the benefits. Then if you spend some time without promotion, your chances for promotions diminish dramatically because you're labeled "with low career velocity".

Internally we know that we are just like IBM in the 80s: a company that just got rid of a host of anti trust issues, with a huge hierarchy, ossified processes all over and so very slow to respond to the competition.

That's because the only way to grow professionaly is by becoming a manager. So people that should and people that shouldn't be a manager are fighting hand and fist to become one. Then we have more hierarchy, and the monster feeds itself...

review_title: My first job straight out of college, strongly recommended
job_title: Systems Validation Engineer in Austin, TX
pros:
Pay is very good, Intel works to make sure they're offering competitive packages to full time employees. Good benefits with a stock purchase plan, and above-average vacation time (3 weeks, but if you've got a good manager they won't hassle you over every hour/day)

Free gym located at the Austin location, as well as a volleyball court and table tennis. Subsidized lunch with an excellent cafeteria! (~$5)

In my position, I was able to learn tons. Managers talk with you to ask what your long-term goals are with the company. They make it easy to switch teams in between projects, which is great for somebody looking to get horizontal mobility.

Bonuses are tied to Intel as a whole...so if Intel does well, so do you.

The onus is on YOU to maintain a healthy work-life balance. I've seen people get burned out here, and I've seen others (like myself) feel like the hours are very reasonable. I mostly stayed in the 40-45 hour range per week. However, I've seen others that worked closer to 60 hours a week.
cons:
The Austin site used to be much smaller. Over the last couple of years, it grew substantially. The Austin site develops and debugs for Atom, the mobile segment of Intel. Unfortunately, the huge design wins haven't come yet.

Management can vary largely from group to group. Personally, I loved my managers and they were great people.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
Great employer with good employee values and benefits globally.  Maybe not the most competitive in the bay area, pay wise, but Intel really does allow for more of a "work/life balance."  Sabbatical is a great benefit that many other places can't compete with and Intel recently announced 2 months paid bonding leave for all new parents, which is a great way to attract female talent.

Intel is also famous for their DOT (development opportunity tool) where employees can sign up and interview for assignments to develop professionally and shape their own career!  This is a great tool.
cons:
The lack of assigned desk space for many employees is frustrating.  It's an open work environment, which is great for traveling employees.  Not so great for employees that come in every day and have to wonder if they will be able to find a clean desk with a working dual monitor display.  Ergonomically, the office is set up to allow for individual adjustments, but it takes time to adjust and readjust daily , if you sit in a mobile space and have to change desks every day.

You really have to own your career and manage your time to take advantage of the benefits well, but I imagine it's probably the same at just about any employer that offers such comprehensive benefits.

job_title: Senior Human Resources Manager in Chandler, AZ
pros: You get to work with the smartest people with the best technology in an environment that always strives for and obsessively works to be better.  Great work life balance, that flexibility is dependent on your manager and your job. The pay is very good but the increases are minute; RSUs for every employee.  Arizona cost of living is good. As everywhere, there are some very good and some very poor managers.
cons: Very patriarchal and familial.  If you are in the family it is great, but you have to be there at least 10 years to become family.  Prior to the 10 years you are treated as an in-law; with respect, but you are the first to go; even if you are the most qualified since you are not yet family. And its harder to become 'family' if you are not white or Indian, regardless of your rank. As a manager, getting your individual projects completed and visible to senior management is the best way, politically, to get ahead, not by developing great employees.

job_title: Electrical Engineer in Fort Collins, CO
pros: Cutting edge design projects; best semiconductor fabs on the planet, bar none. Wages are great, bonuses are awesome.
cons: Intel prints money with ON-TIME semiconductor wafers. Electrical design of the circuits that are printed thereon is, in the unspoken corporate opinion, a necessary evil to allow the printing of said money.  Intel expects inordinate amounts of time from electrical designers and all engineers to meet frequently RIDICULOUS schedules.  That's fine when you're young without attachments, but as you mature, start families, etc., they demand that same amount of time. Evenings and weekends are pretty much expected, though very seldom will a manager actually tell you that directly (because it's illegal, of course). <Oh, wait,now they just laid-off 15% of your work force and the schedules have not been altered (great...)>  Non-compliance is punished in the antiquated forced relative ranking that painfully occupies months each year.  Intel does NOT want older, experienced engineers; they want Recent College Graduates (or third world engineers) with no life and lots of time to spend on the really nice, company sponsored laptops.  Even if they do a crummy job, they are much cheaper to employ.

review_title: Intel.  A great place to work if your lucky enough to have a good manager.
job_title: Senior Validation Engineer in Chandler, AZ
pros: Work is interesting and challenging.  Compensation and benefits are relatively good.
cons: Low level management is not adequately supervised or scrutinized when problems and conflicts occur.  Senior management have high ideals but do not require the same of lower management who work directly with the majority of the work force.  Second level managers and above have pretty much a free hand at how they run their organizations and are not required to follow Intel policy or culture as long as the groups goals are being met.  Scrutiny only occurs if some big problem arises that could affect the groups short term goals.  A single contributors complaint of policy violations will get no ones attention and can lead to being targeted by the low level management for termination.  The HR open door process for terminated employees is a joke and is only there to support the management and ensure the terminated employee stays terminated.

review_title: Good place to work, provided you have the right job you want at the right place and team
job_title: Reliability Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: It has a system that "works" -- politics is minimal, great management team with experience, get to stay at the forefront of technology, moving inside the organization allows for experiencing various roles within a large, mostly coherent and thriving corporation. Once one is in the right team (the definition of "right" would differ from person to person), it can be a great and satisfying place to work, and moving within teams facilitates that somewhat. However, the latter might also entail moving from one place to another. Their U.S. sites also seem to be located at some of the most geographically polarized regions, especially with regards to their climate.
cons: Owing to its size, growth opportunities can be limited -- and might take some "luck". Compensation is not the best in the industry, unless stability is counted in. Their package for compensation is changing over the years to more "cash based" and less retention (stock) oriented. Their recent primary problem seems to have been that a newer management team has to "correct" the problems of an older team, and that leads to layoffs and restructuring affecting the average worker's life. Some lack of accountability can probably be attributed to senior management for such issues. Even within a given management team, some of their investment decisions in new areas have proven to be unwise requiring considerable corrections (again affecting the ordinary worker) for fixing those.

pros: Joined Intel many years ago. It was a great company full of opportunity, stability and promise for advancement. It is currently a company without leadership or direction. Realizing this is the "pros" section, one positive comment is that the company has allowed for continual technical growth that will tremendously help in finding future career opportunities.
cons:
Intel values quantity over quality. It does not matter if it does make sense to complete a project as long as it is completed regardless of impact, business need or company direction. There are many talented and wise individuals that realize this is a problem but the company is too large to be able to rectify the situation and address the issues at hand.
Intel is currently transitioning to a "Virtuous Cycle" business model that will shift focus away from what Intel does best, and that is manufacturing. These are truly dark days at Intel.

pros: Intel is a great reputable company with good benefits.  I think everyone should work at Intel just to get in shape for their next job since it is much like going to Boot Camp.  It definitely raised my skill level and abilities.  Intel is very big on training and you will have more training than any other company.  You need to be able to fit into the culture of the company and if you come from another company (and not fresh out of school) it will seem like being on a different planet with a whole different language and will need to learn how to speak 'Intel'.
cons: Very rough culture with not much tolerance of less than perfection.  A bunch of Type A personalities that are also work-aholics.  Diversity is present however, everyone is expected to fit in to the strong Intel culture and it is almose 'cult-like' with a 'hazing-like' probation initiation.  Many people PhD's, etc. that have extremely arrogant attitudes.  If you don't adapt, you will quickly sink into the bottom 10% and then be pushed out the door (fired).  I wasn't but got out for another opportunity.  I'm glad I left because had I stayed, I might have had permenant brain-washing.  I hear that for long time Intel folks, it's difficult to assimulate into other companies due to the cult culture (it's not the real world - seriously!)  I'm glad I worked there but also glad to 'escape'.

review_title: Great place to work & very good opportunities but pay could be better
job_title: Technical Marketing Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Overall it's a very good company to work for.  Most of the work is very interesting and cutting edge, especially in engineering & marketing.  There are lots of opportunities to move around, both temporary and permanent.  Benefits and perks are generally pretty good but perks will vary depending on the job.  Management tends to be flexible on things like hours and telecommuting, again depends on the job though.
cons: My only major grip is compensation - even in very profitable times (like now), annual salary increases are really poor, averaging only 2-3%, which doesn't even keep up with inflation (A very good raise is only like 5%, even on promos).  Bonuses make up for some of that but they have also sharply cut retirement contributions, stock purchase plans and stock options over the last 10 years.  Always negotiate the highest starting salary possible if you take a job here.

review_title: Lots of Great Reasons to Work for Intel
job_title: Technical Project Manager in Chandler, AZ
pros:
- If you want to work with smart, driven people... this is the place to work
- The benefits (medical ins., onsite services, etc.) are nice 
- The pay is good when compared to non technical industries
- Great place for those who like continuous learning
- Onsite services are a big plus (health centers, gyms, etc.)
- 4 weeks of vacation after 10 years
- Discounts on Intel stock purchases
- Senior management really does want diversity in the ranks.
- Great opportunity to work with others on a global scale.
cons:
- The pay is only average when compared to other tech. companies
- A 40 hour work week would be a pipe dream.  I didn't mind, but if you have kids at home....
- This is a big corporation and life impacting decisions (aka layoffs) are made at the corporate level.   If you don't like this, you should rethink whether you really want to work at a very large company.
- Generally speaking, older employees are not as desirable as younger ones.
- This is a technology company, so expect layoffs every couple of years.  Even if you are not impacted, chances are you will know someone who is/was which is tough as well.

review_title: 60% spent on meetings; 40% spent on work...if there is any
pros:
-Insurance is free; Other benefits are pretty great
-You can work from home if you're not feeling great, if the kids are sick, if you have an appointment, etc.
-Overall time is pretty flexible as long as you put the hours in
-Tuition reimbursement
-People here are generally really nice and helpful. Makes work worth sitting through
cons:
-People are obsessed with meetings. You have meetings to discuss what will be said in your next meetings
-Organization is pretty bad. No one really knows what's going on or who to ask to find out what to do.
-Communication is also poor. I think I missed the part of orientation where we're given a key to decipher what the heck people are trying to write in emails. 
-If you have to work closely with colleagues across the world, expect to work through the evenings. Or better yet, sit through meetings that accomplish nothing during your evenings.
-There can be weeks where you sit around doing nothing even when you ask for more work. Then with a snap of the fingers, you have people jumping down your throat to get a project done that was due weeks ago, but that you didn't know existed.
-No more Great Place to Work incentives. CEO is chipping away at benefits, including removing cups from the cafes.
-Employees are unhappy and underpaid.

job_title: Partner Marketing Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Intel is one of the most ethical companies I've ever seen. Their admirable, pro-active industry leadership on conflict free minerals in the supply chain is an excellent proof point. Aside from ethics, they have other great cultural aspects like the "disagree and commit" philosophy and the focus on process excellence. Finally, Intel is a very profitable company, which does wonders for the morale of a company.
cons:
The company-wide con I can speak to is the significant strategic shift happening at Intel currently. It's also a pro however. They are finally making a long-overdue true commitment to moving beyond the CPU and beyond the PC/server markets. It's the right strategic move and hats off Brian K (the CEO) for having the vision and guts to try and steer this giant ship. So it's a pro for the long term health of Intel as a business, but it's creating a lot of short term friction and uncertainty. 

More specific to my former realm, the Intel marketing department is hurting. Marketing at a component manufacturer was always destined to be difficult, but morale and leadership has taken a significant turn for the worse since around 2014.

pros: Great salaries, very smart people.
cons: Governed by gray heads that have very high salaries, implementing ANY type of change is extremely difficult.  50% of time is spent managing your career, so it is difficult to get things done.  Everyone is concerned about getting ahead, no team-work encouragement.  Company does not understand UX and only a few UX leaders have UX training/background or interest.  Young people are highly discouraged to do anything innovative, leadership is not based on meritocracy but "grade levels" that are arbitrary and mostly related to politics and not accomplishments.  Recognition is hard to come by.  Different ways of working and solving problems are not encouraged.  Engineering mentality rules, design and social sciences are second rated citizens that constantly fear the future of their job (and thus become very territorial).  Most people that are good leave the company soon or are "managed out", the ones that stay become either very comfortable in a 9-5 lifestyle, or become cut-throat to advance their careers and agendas.  Woman and hispanics have a very difficult time advancing (very little representation in upper management positions).

pros: Excellent pay and benefits, many great people to work with/for, lots of company functions that you can participate in. I enjoyed my time at Intel. Also some people can telecommute on a part-time basis - a big plus!
cons: Be prepared to learn to speak in acronyms and you'll be working with a lot of people from India. There are *many* meetings to attend in every group. There is SO MUCH red tape, though - the wheels of progress move VERY slowly. It can be extremely frustrating at times. Also, everyone has their own agenda and you should always watch your back. It's every man for himself and they all want to get ahead. Also everyone lives in their little cubicle where you don't see anyone else. Be very quiet - people are working - if you need to speak with someone, take them into an empty conference room. Any kind of external noise is frowned upon, and you can understand why. Respect everyone else's need for quiet to be able to concentrate. They will expect your whole life to revolve around Intel.

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Intel is a great company to work for. The CPUs/GPUs you work on are next generation and very relevant to your life and just about everyone else's life throughout the world. Intel is one of those companies that when you say where you work people know and have respect for you. I find the work to be challenging, and the people to be nice. Intel as a company is helpful to the communities it lives in by supporting many employee volunteering programs. With matching employee contributions, Intel supports what its employees support. Intel has even put a lot of effort in going green. My best wishes to everyone.
cons: You will instantly become tech support for everyone in your family. That is funny, but there are some serious cons. Intel is still a great company to work for, but management has been slowly moving away from caring about their employees and toward caring about themselves. Hopefully, this trend will stop and they will again realize how Intel came to be Intel one of the greatest companies in the world.

review_title: A manufacturing excellence company confounded by product development
pros:
Great benefits
Excellent salary
Large company with no end of challenging problems to solve
Corporate jets!
Depending on your role, excellent opportunities for advancement
cons:
Clueless about product development (they make chips. Period.)
Clueless, mostly, about product design, user experience, customer experience
Massive bureaucracy, six left hands don't know what eight right hands have already done
Too many people on projects, because of paranoid attitudes toward survival
Depending on your role, very limited options for advancement
Completely antiquated performance review processes that pit employees against one another

pros:
* benefits are great
* lean approach
* approachable managers (although some are not)
* flexible work options (but limited to some groups)
cons:
* even under one roof, there are differences in department's practice. No standardization of work / processes across departments / teams
* different managers have different demands / requirements
* stressful working hours. Some groups work over weekends, some don't. Depending on managers
* too much bureaucracy and pushing of work to others. It's a game of who talks and pass the buck better, not who is the actual person responsible
* no ownership of mistakes or processes. You end up doing other's work/resolution for them even though it's not your responsibility
* the tools are provided but you have to find your own work-life balance unless you have a good leader. Example: the game room is available but how can I use them if I'm working til night?
* difficult to move up and innovate. Some people stay up and are too comfortable resulting in bottle-necking / no opportunities for others

review_title: Amazing Technology. Manufacturing is a thrilling amalgamation of many aspects of Modern Sciences and Engineering.
job_title: Senior Process Technology Development Engineer in Portland, OR
pros:
Feels good to be building the fundamental computing chips to power information technology. 
Wide diversity in educational, cultural, ethnic backgrounds of employees. 
Great technical depth in research and engineering. The underlying challenges of technical complexity and market profitability make problem solving more exciting. 
Plenty of opportunities for multidisciplinary international collaborations and a rich team environment.  
Recent changes in senior management seem to favor technical credibility and past achievements rather than personal familiarities. 
Good pay, bonuses , benefits etc. Intel takes care of employees.

job_title: Senior Process Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Benefits are equivalent or better to what you'd find somewhere else and the cost of living is lower.
cons:
I'm posting this review to help new Ph.D job seekers avoid the situation I found after I joined Intel as a process engineer.  First, most of what they tell you at the job interview is incorrect.  Anyone receiving a completely honest picture of the job would likely turn it down, so a lot of sugar coating occurs.  

After you show up, things change.  24x7 on call for months on end.  Boring repetitive work.  Insulting and downright rude management.  What's not to like?  

You'll also find that those skills you fought so hard for in graduate school aren't even required and someone with much less schooling could do exactly the same thing.  Most of the work involves tracking, copying and pasting.  These are low level engineering jobs, but internal policy requires that they be filled with recent graduates holding advanced degrees.  Many people leave after a year or two, and Intel considers this to be the cost of doing business.  The general attitude is "shut up and get back to work or get out."

People in the software side of the business seem to be genuinely happy and well treated.  Its a large company and great places to work do exist.  Just stay away from the manufacturing and process development work.

pros: You get to work with some of the smartest people in the world. The benefits are very good, including restricted stock units for most employees. Base pay is lower than competition but total compensation, during good years, is very good. No formal PTO policy allows for flexibility with time off, and in may non-manufacturing jobs there is the ability to work from home (manager dependent).
cons: Intel is no longer the desirable company it used to be. Some of the best talent in the company sees it as a stepping stone to get to better tech companies like Google, Facebook, Amazon, and Apple. Constant reorganizations in all departments takes away any feeling of job security. This in-turn makes it difficult to focus and work in a productive manner. The yearly review process pit employees against each other instead of accomplishments per the job description. Intel is one of the few companies out there that still uses a forced distribution model for yearly reviews, so there is always someone that will get a bad review even if they performed to their job expectations. Many managers there have no business being managers. They see it as a role to check off the list to become a principle engineer. Intel is still very much a good-ole' boys club where room for career development is heavily dependent on your "status" in the club.

-Very rare to see a graduate from top10 university. At intel they say college doesn't really matter. But to some degree it really does. Now that I got out of intel and I work at a FANG company, I see many people from top tier schools. And these are people who survived a tougher competition. Lets face it, the competition you need to go through to get into a FANG company is likely x3 than getting into Intel. And hence you see more people from top 10 schools at a fang company. And these people are really hard working. At intel, the parking lot is half empty at 4:30pm. 
-The CEO literally acknowledges that intel salary is 65% percentile, hence thinks its okay to hire D level engineers (65% would score a D in school). Please think carefully if a company can attract top tier, ambitious talent with 65% salary.

review_title: Intel - A great place for a long term career, but excitement is limited
pros: It is a large company with many opportunities.  In addition, Intel encourages people to try new things and expand their skills into different areas.  For a technology company, it is quite stable and works to ensure employees have interesting and challenging jobs.  One nice thing about working for Intel is that you can manage large projects or teams that you might never get a chance to do at many other companies.  You also have a degree of freedom in putting your ideas into action, although justifying the cost and wading through the red-tape is getting more and more difficult.  Overall, I like working here and find it enjoyable and interesting.
cons: Like any large company, it can be bureacratic and relatively slow to react.  Even though Intel provides stock options, they are worth far less than in the past.  Back in the 1990's even as an individual contributor, you could reasonably expect to retire a millionaire, but those days are long gone.  Intel can be a difficult place to work if you are not highly motivated.  Most managers here will not closely manage you and you are often left on your own to make important decisions.  This is not always a downside, but can be for those people who need lots of direct, regular manager interface.

review_title: Great starting point that will leave you dissatisfied in the long term.
job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
1.  The name recognition is valuable on your resume.  The name alone causes a fair amount of respect when speaking to potential employers.
2.  Great if you have a family.  The work load is very predictable and job security is very high.
3.  Training - they spend a great deal of time showing you how products are made and how that impacts your role.
4.  Pay - they are in most cases very competitive at the onset of your employment.
5.  Benefits - excellent medical, dental, vision programs.
6.  Other compensation - Share buyback, employee bonus, and other incentives add considerably to your compensation.
cons:
1.  Slow decision making - You complete your analysis in a matter of days and spend months convincing people that you are right and changes should be made.
2.  Sinking ship syndrome - Current negative personnel growth means all the good people are leaving and all the schmo's are sticking around.
3.  Narrow scope - you will become very proficient at an incredibly narrow portion of the business.  These skills are frequently hard to transition into other industries.
4.  Management - Direct managers in my experience had little skill in managing advanced employees.

review_title: Would not recommend as an employer
pros: Sabbatical, on site medical, no charge for drinks or fruit, the safest place I have ever worked in the semiconductor industry, no cost medical benefit option, 401k that offers a brokerage account where individual stocks can be traded, 401k company contribution is not dependent on employee contribution.
cons: The Rio Rancho site has management in place (below the site manager) that has been in place for a long time and operates on how well they like you.  There is minimal reward for being an innovator and diligent employee.  The pay is average at best, and the stock options offered to manufacturing technicians are laughable.  The 401k company contributions have only gone down year after year for the past decade while medical costs continue to increase as a percentage for the employee.  The last layoff candidates were selected based on whether or not stock options were granted (stock options can be with held from employees when a manager wishes to retaliate for whatever reason he/she chooses) even though a successful review is presented.  A large quantity of unqualified people in positions they do not belong in (engineers with no formal science/engineering education from respected schools (such as the University of Phoenix...pay for your degree approach)) work at this site which propagates the good ole boy culture.

job_title: Embedded Software Engineer in Folsom, CA
pros:
Job security if you can join the team dealing with IP.
Good company for retire.
cons:
IP protection - This is the root of all other problems. Competitors are not interested in Intel's IP. They already have what Intel has and even more. IP protection in Intel, now, is used as Job Security and it is the main reason of lagging all projects. Although people dealing with IP cannot support all on-going projects(begging support from them), they don't open information enough for other people who can handle issues by themselves. They keep saying "this is intel IP should be protected"(to other Intel employee). Intel should be able to distinguish things have to be protected and things have to be shared.
Politics - Long history of the company created too much chopped tasks and each task has its owner. Now, even small request for a tiny thing is not easy. IP protection adds even more political activities here. You can easily find people dealing with phone all day.
CANNOT FIX THE PROBLEM - The problems above are created for long time by people who worked for Intel. They are, now, owner of IP or management.
Not good for NCG - Difficult to get big picture because you will work on small thing and there's not enough sharing information.

review_title: Good mix of challenges and work life balance
pros:
Intel is the leader in CPU manufacturing. You get to work on cutting edge products. You get the opportunity to learn and work on the core concepts of CPU design, architecture and validation. In addition to the CPU segment, Intel has presence in other fields such as Security (through McAfee) and some leading scientific areas such as Machine Learning.

As part of Great Place To Work attempts, Intel India provides a wide range of benefits covering practically all aspects of day-to-day life. Personal, Accident and Health insurances, Internet reimbursement, Commuting options, Work From Home, Gym, Yoga, Aerobics classes, Team outings, regular workshops covering various topics and the list is endless.

There are numerous opportunities for an employee to grow as a professional and as an individual.
cons: Some technologies at Intel are specific to the company and may not be relevant outside. I believe this is applicable, in general, to many big companies. So, if you are working in such an area, it is advisable that you develop your general purpose skills as well. However, since Intel has huge number of areas and teams, you will always have the opportunity to do so.

pros: The pay is good, benefits are good, sabbatical every 4 or 7 years is great. Good vacation time. Co-workers are amazing, hard working, vast majority want to help, do the right thing, won't stab you in the back.
cons:
Little to no advancement opportunities, Extremely politically correct culture. If you aren't Black, Hispanic, or a technical Female, you are second class citizen. You'll be passed over for promotions/advancement opportunities in favor of these "URM's". During Startups, you'll be working 80-100+ hours a week. Due to layoffs the last 2 years in a row, headcount is very low, work level expectation never went down to compensate, still have many useless meetings to attend instead of doing actual work.
Management will pick their couple favorites, cover for their mistakes,  hang others out to dry so they have someone to offer up for an Improvement Required review, due to forced distributions. Layoffs each year of the "IRs" has created an extreme negative morale situation that isn't going away, and has been like this for 5 years now with grueling startup pace + recent layoffs.
Intel has had a monopoly for many years now, CPU's are finally becoming commoditized, despite recent Apple design win, company outlook not looking great, likely more layoffs to follow each year as they cut headcount to maintain profit margin. At some point this will break the company if nothing changes.

review_title: Top level managers are good, but watch out for mid-level management
pros: One of the last and truly excellent manufacturing capable corporations in the US.   Not that the automobile industry isn't a capable, just their leadership seems to be poor.  Top level managers often seem to be well chosen for capability and smarts.
cons: For all their emphasis on competitive ratings of employees, too often poor performers continually get promoted or protected.  This is especially true at the mid-level management level where I've had to work for a good number of total incompetents.   There's often an unfortunately high degree of belief that managers can be successful managing without any technical competence.  This is fine if you are not in a technical group, but if you are, it's rather unfortunate for those unlucky enough to have to endure it.

review_title: They work you hard, pay you well, and don't appreciate you....
pros: Compensation package is very good. Salary and bonuses are hard to beat. The medical, dental, and vision is completely covered. the 401k gets contributed to by Intel whether you contribute or not. Intel is also very "meritocracy" oriented - seniority in the "union" and "govt' worker" sense does not exist. You get ahead by achieving. Intel will also allow you to take on as much work and achieve as much as your can take on yourself. Opportunities are great and plentiful - though, they diminish somewhat as you grow into the higher/senior grade levels. It's a great place to start your career off.
cons: Very stressful place to work if you don't manage it. They care mostly about results, and not very much about its people. Intel creates a culture in which its employees have to put in the hours to get the job done - this especially is amplified or made worse by the fact that many projects are cross-country, where you have to attend meetings that align with the other site. Israel, Malaysia, etc. are the tough ones. They also tend to promote people that were good technically into management roles, and many times these people do not make good managers - somehow, they continue to exist in mgmt roles based upon their technical knowledge.

review_title: Great place to work for low to mid experience
pros:
Great Perks
Good flexibility for taking off
Great Benefits
They bend over backward to keep you comfortable in your job
       Quarterly trips, both by the individual team and the whole site
Great management from top to bottom - they try to keep you informed as they can
cons:
Intel Austin has a recipe for doing things, and it mostly involves using low tech and compensating using large amount of people/resources to compensate.
If you are a new hire or low experienced, this shouldn't matter because you need to learn the ropes anyways
If you are a high experienced person, it will be difficult to acclimate to the brute force way of doing things.
If you are a person who likes to have control or some input of how things are done, I would not recommend Intel Austin as a place to work. There may be some other sites where this may not apply.
Changing things may not be possible because the majority of the methodologies are not created in the Austin area.

review_title: Intellectually stimulating. Great place to work!
job_title: Senior Strategy and Product Planning Manager in Hillsboro, OR
pros: You are working with the best and brightest people on the planet. The culture demands total intellectual honesty and an impersonal and constructive approach to confronting issues and staying ahead of changes. There is never a dull moment there. There are also so many avenues for personally and professionally growing in your knowledge of the industry and in functional areas as well. Also, the compensation package is excellent especially if the stock is doing well.
cons: Intel can make being innovative difficult as it will pull and shut down projects before they hardly get going. You have to be comfortable with it and with changing course or direction on a moment's notice. It is not a terribly structured environment in terms of reporting lines. Working in the business development, strategy and/or marketing areas requires a lot of cross-divisional effort with lots of travel between Intel sites to make sure any program or product is sufficiently serviced and coordinated. That requires a lot of travel and effort. Work-life balance does suffer as a result.

pros: Intel pays well at all levels.   If you are a junior employee, it can be a decent place to work.
cons:
Management style varies significantly.  Some are bullies.  Some border on insanity.   The annual review system is a joke.  It's become as bad as a 

It's stock is still below it's high from 2000.  The stock fluctuates up and down for a reason.  It's edge in technology is eroding and it will hit a wall in a few years.   The cost per transistor will start going up with little to no performance increase.  

Intel always lagged when it came to new markets and applications.  It lost the phone and tablet market.  It simply can't compete on price.  It's foothold on the server market and manufacturing technology kept it afloat.  But, it can't survive on it's momentum forever.

One shouldn't plan on a long term future. Intel has a bias against older workers.   It's cheaper for them to hire young foreign workers desperate to get an sponsor for a visa than continue to employ their older workers.  For example, the average age of an Intel employee in the United States is 42.6. The average age of an employee laid off last August was 48.1.

Managers lie... lie... lie....  Honesty is not a value.  While the Code of Conduct gives mention to fairness and openness, managers lie without fear of repercussions.  Just ask anyone from HR about repercussions for managers who lie.  They will not answer.

review_title: Get Ready to be Taken Advantage Of
pros: Pay and benefits make it hard to leave.
cons: Will take advantage of hard workers. Same pay, same title, same job, but because you do what it takes to ensure your group, team, and boss all look good, you will endure additional restrictions like trying to schedule time off. Basically your boss will come to solely rely on you to do everything anyone else is not doing what they are supposed to. Its so bad that you'll be only allowed to take days off only if one of the other hard workers hasn't scheduled a day off. And from what I've seen that equates to only about 20% of the team. So now you have the normal "no more than 3 people off at a time (from the whole group of 20)" AND "no more than 1 person off from the group of hard workers (approx 4 people including yourself)".

review_title: This is a great place to work for robots, or lobotomized humans.
job_title: Marketing Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros: The good aspect about working at Intel is that politics is not tolerated and everyone has a voice at this company. Intel lives by the credo that it's knowledge power triumphs over position power. However, that's not always the case depending on the manager you have. It has got a hard-working culture, but if you like the fast pace then this place for you. They have great a great product roadmap so there's always something new on the horizon to market.  Intel offers alot of internal training and it has good cross-company internal communication, with good resources to back up good ideas.
cons: Intel has a strong work culture of being paranoid that can work against it. There is too much tire-kicking on plans to the point where questions about a project seem irrelevant turning meetings into a trash-fest. Its attitude towards customers and competitors is often arrogant. Worse aspect is the work environment still rely on cube culture and everything is grey. There's very little commadarie across divisions or within divisions, and this has a dulling effect on employees over time. There's very little excitement and much too much processes that makes the work feel like a drudge. e.g. Monthly status reports are written up every month for all employees, and it's clear no one reads them.

review_title: Wish I could have the year I spent at Intel back!
job_title: Ecosystem Marketing Manager in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Competitive pay in the local area, LOTS of smart people.  There are good places w/in the company, but it totally depends on whom you get as a manager as to whether or not you will be successful.
cons: managers whose motto is "what have you done for me lately", a management team that thrives on fear & intimidation.  I was in a group where both my direct manager and the director were arrogant and headstrong, and it made for some very unpleasant times.   My manager expected inordinate amounts of time from me, and not that I'm unwilling to give it for a position I love, but for someone who constantly terrorizes and berates you, is it really worth it?  I complained to HR about his behavior, and was told my complaints were unfounded.  I did some investigating on my own and found that he had been demoted and moved out of a group after mistreating a number of employees.. and then 3 years later, he's up to his same tricks in a different department.   If you are thinking of working here, be VERY CAREFUL and ask to talk to former group members to see if you can get the real scoop on your potential new boss.

review_title: Unique benefits & rewarding work, but Company lacks transparency.
pros:
- Very cool place to work, you get to do engineering work with industry leading products.

- Excellent people, everyone I have worked with across multiple organizations has outstanding professionalism, but still knows how to have a good time.

- You accumulate vacation time to spend in one chunk every 4 or 7 years, equivalent to about a 5-6 days of vacation a year. Every year, you get ~3 weeks of vacation + a 4 week "sabbatical" every 4 years, or an 8 week sabbatical every 7 years.

- New benefit, generous paid paternity leave.
cons:
- Some benefits are slashed on the back of these new benefits, 401(k) contributions have been going down and they did away with my preferred health insurance plan and a new bonus structure that pays out less.

- The performance review process is annoying and very political, as well as not very transparent to employees.

review_title: Blue Chip Barge that's slow to turn
job_title: Physical Design Engineer in Chandler, AZ
pros:
Stable, they make headcount reductions with voluntary separation packages, or redeployment, but they rarely outright fire anyone.  And people that were part of a reduction usually found another position within the company within a year.
Bonuses for higher level engineers are good, and the quarterly profit sharing bonus was a nice perk.
Retirement contribution requires no employee contribution.
Recognition is frequent and at various levels.
Ample opportunity to meet with upper level execs, in open forums, lunch groups, or even 1:1s.
Vacation is not really tracked and neither are work hours, you are reviewed based on your results.
cons:
They rarely fire anyone, even those with consistently poor performance, or with numerous complaints filed against them.
Constant reorganizations.  Impossible to keep the acronyms and hierarchy straight.
Lots of cancelled projects, and failed businesses.  See Broxton, or OnCue.
Only 5% stock participation.
Massive.  Often requires collaboration with multiple timezones.
Acquisitions are slow to integrate and even slower to produce results.

review_title: Great place to work and learn about new hardware technologies.
pros: Work on enabling cutting edge hardware technology. Great opportunity to work with people with decades of experience in the hardware industry.
cons: Intel is a meritocracy; technical proficiency is not enough for going up this ladder, it will require excruciating dedication to exceed expectations and development of soft skills. Be ready to exist in persistent crunch mode. Still, promotions will be glaciar slow and dependent on your organization's performance and resources, even if the whole company is doing great. Unless you are offered to hop into an opening in the organization with a better pay, rotations within the company will further hinder chances of promotions.

review_title: If you can master PPT and follow a process, work here...
pros: Intel is an "OK" place to work.  After a few years it becomes a job, not a passion or career.  At the end of the day the company is so big you scratch your head and wonder if you are even making a difference.  Maybe it just the place for the person who would excel at a smaller start up type company.  There are some good things -- Flexibility of schedules and sabbatical.
cons: The Beuracracy at Intel can be overwhelming.  Every few months we re-org and depending on the year decide if we will flatten the org and lay off managers or just add more manager for career growth (who will be redeployed the next time management decides we need to flatten the org. There is a constant need for "slides" for every meeting -- I am not sure some people could funtion without them.  But to ensure they can still finction I am sure there is a process that they can use to get their job done -- Intel has a process for EVERYTHING, including how to walk down the stairs.  I am not kidding!

review_title: demanding workplace perfect for a strongly grounded and balanced worker
pros: Lots of exciting projects and programs. Good work is recognized. Many, many, excellent and smart human beings to work with. The company is doing some excellent things to make the world a better place.
cons: You could feel like a cog. Lots of silo'ing and empire building.  The work can be very demanding and the place will eat up whatever you give it.  It's possible to work 60 or more hours per week, but only if you let yourself do that. You can balance your life you just need to put effort into holding the balance and letting things slip. Just know your priorities and your business groups priorities really well and be prepared to demonstrate how your work aligns with those priorities.  Don't sweat the small stuff. More things than one thinks are often small stuff.

review_title: Good pay, no life to spend it on.
job_title: Process Technical Director Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Great compensation and benefits.  Paternity leave is amazing and encouraged.  In house training is good.  Some managers really care employees.
cons:
Work life balance is terrible:
You are expected to respond to issues 24/7 within 30 mins and be able to be onsite within 2 hrs.  The fab is chronically understaffed for engineers because management does not consider on-call time as work time.
Job stability is non-existent:
During recent round of lay-offs everyone in my organization that had been working longer than 3 years was fired.  Many people leave due to burn out.
Career growth is working for the right manager at the right time:
Success at Intel trickles down.  If a manager is successful and promoted those under them also get promoted regardless of the whether their are more qualified or senior people in other organizations.
Fear of failure holds the technology development hostage:
At every level it is made clear that you will be fired for any mistakes.  This means any fixes you come up to make the job easier get caught in the limbo of is it important enough pursue.  The result is, as an engineer you are forced to continuously put out fires rather than actually solve issues.

pros: Knowledgeable people, everybody want to succeed here a lot of competition. The pay is not bad but can be better.
cons: The company is dealing with a great numbers of awful and inexperience managers some do not even have any technical background to be leading a technical group in the first place.  If you have found a great manager my best advice is to stake with him and maybe not change group till you are sure where you will land. There is a lot of gossiping going on at the work place mainly the style of management create such hostile work environment. Some groups at Intel become like gangsters to get admission is to state your loyalty to the manager and their own culture  while the company policy dictate another. My experience is HR is not to be trusted, they are not helpful just a bunch of bureaucrats looking for their next pay check. If you are ever in a dilemma with a manager better look for a new job in a new group. Overall do not trust anyone nor any manager let's time be your ally, then you can let your guard down and that is after 3 years of working with them.
