job_title: Engineering Technician in Rio Rancho, NM
pros: Outstanding benefits (sabbatical every 7 years is awesome), some of the most intelligent coworkers in the world, extremely safe environment (safety is #1 value), competitive pay, cutting-edge technology work, ease of lateral transfer to other positions, diverse culture.
cons: Dog-eat-dog environment (majority of coworkers are very competitive and tend to be back-stabbers) - this is almost necessary in order to get an above-average rating and stay employed at Intel, although it didn't used to be that way.  Poor management - I probably only had maybe four decent supervisors during my nineteen-year tenure.  Intel has never learned how to hire good managers - they take engineers and try to convert them into managers (rarely works well).  Difficult to advance - mentorship is very poor; Intel tried to start a management mentorship program a few years ago, but nothing ever became of it.  Poor work/life balance for exempts - engineers in R&D especially are worked to death and have horrible morale, infecting the entire team.  Uncertain future - Intel used to be strictly a processor maker, but now seem to be floundering.  Latest lay-off was done extremely poorly, with employees who were good performers (maybe a bit older and higher-paid) let go.

job_title: Software Engineer Advanced in Toronto, ON
pros:
- Very smart and friendly people who can help grow you professionally
- Very interesting and difficult engineering problems to solve - can get a bit addictive sometimes
- Management does cares about your professional development and well-being
- Great downtown location, compensations and perks (free metropass, etc.)
- Low stress level - rarely have strict deadlines, and you can take time to innovate.
- Lots of autonomy and flexibility in terms of what you work on, where and when, etc.
- Not a lot of drama or politics.
- Decent dedication to doing right software engineering, despite imperfections.
cons:
- IT infrastructure (computing farm, network storage, etc.) can't keep up with engineering needs - you can't run as many experiments as you want
- Management sometimes overworked - means less time to care about your progress/development
- Despite usually low stress level, occasionally you still need to just focus on getting something done instead of getting it done right.
- Understaffed. Getting better since Intel acquired us.
- Corporate culture is very good, but probably not as newer dynamic as places like Facebook.
- Can feel distant from the rest of Intel since the acquisition. What the hell are they doing anyway?
- Toronto Yorkville office could be a bit more colourful!

review_title: Really a Great Place To Work!
pros:
Might depend on manager/dept, but thankfully very little office politics - a no blame environment and excellent office atmosphere. Main focus was the work and ample time and space given to perform well. 
Most important (for me at least): Good level of mutual trust among colleagues that everyone is giving their best effort. No one was ever called a slacker. Mistakes were not prosecuted, they were accepted as a fact of life and the only focus was on how to overcome them and reduce them moving forward. This is exactly the type of environment a workplace should have!
Day-to-day management processes are clear and hassle-free. Great level of support from anciliary depts (IT, budgeting, HR, etc).
cons:
If your team is good, you will be hard pressed to find any cons of working here. I certainly can't! Would not have left if it wasn't for personal reasons.
People do talk about too much work - yes, it can be a bit of a problem - but considering the huge salary, the environment, and the fact that you are working for one of the pioneering companies in the world, what else can you expect?

review_title: The Once and Future King... Can Intel Be A True Leader Again?
job_title: Technical Project Manager in Chandler, AZ
pros: High tech company. Sabbaticals every seven years, telecommuting policies that allow workers to work from home one day a week, 3 weeks of vacation the first year you work there and 4 weeks vacation after working there 10 years. Reasonably good pay and their bonus program is a substantial part of the total compensation. Lots of challenging work and opportunties to bite off as much as you can chew (or more). Side benefits like free soft drinks, coffee and tea from the cafe is nice. Free fruit is a great way to eat healthier. Worldwide presence and opportunities for travel.
cons: "Redeployments" are done with no logic. Extremely talented resources (people) are let go that have a wealth of legacy knowledge and experience. Like other large, major corporations, it's very easy to get caught up in the bureaucracy of doing things just to support efforts from on high that, at the end of the day, don't really add a lot of value.  Taking away the ability to work remotely (no physical office presence in any Intel building) forced many talented individuals to leave the company when they chose not to relocate to an approved site. Uncertainty on whether you will have a job or not 6 months from now is a definite downside.

pros:
Depending on job, work/life balance can be great.  Good benefits including stock purchase, retirement contributions, stock allocations.  Very ethical corporation, makes one pround to work there.

The opportunity to try several job functions through lateral moves is very high.  One can pretty easily get general management explerience by taking jobs in different functional ares.  It is accepted practice to move jobs every 1-2 years. 

People are very friendly and talented.  A focus on family is obvious with alot of flexibility for work/life with young families.  Of course this can change depending on the manager.  Great people to work with, most have a strong affinity for Intel.
cons:
Hierarchial, very large corporation can make one feel lost or detached from the prodcuts and customer.  Power and decisions seem limited to the few of est. 85k employees, although I suspect this is typical of large corporations. 

Leadership program is limited to mid-managers with nothing for rising talent.

Not necessarily a bad thing, but you must own your own employment and have plan for promotions and career, they will not be handed to you.

Often times working in remote groups.  Allows for good flexibility for working from home and flexible hours but can limit the amount of comradery and teamwork one feels when everyone in the same place.

review_title: Not such a great place to work - especially if you are an admin!
job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Decent salary, great benefits and café onsite.
cons: No offices means admins having to book conference rooms, no break areas on each floor (have to go down to first floor for water/coffee/tea which is a hassle if you are on the top floor of a six story building) and no dedicated transportation system which is strange considering all the big tech companies such as Google, Yahoo and Apple have them. Admins are frequently asked to do things that are beyond the scope of reasonable requests. Since the company has a seven day a week work environment, admins will find that their managers want them to work on evenings and weekends. You can try to set boundaries but you have to stand firm or they will run over them. Also, it seems that it is okay to have managers who will intimidate and terrorize thinking they are helping you learn but in fact are actually creating an unprofessional and extremely stressful environment. One last thing, while there may be great benefits, you will find it hard to use them as management frowns upon admins leaving early, coming in late or working from home when you have medical appointments. Everyone else seems to have that flexibility but the admins do not.

review_title: Lack of market knowledge and business skills, toxic culture, cronyism and nepotism
job_title: Strategic Business Development in Portland, OR
pros: Above average pay, especially in Oregon.  Excellent benefits.
cons: Intel is in the Dark Ages.  Archaic processes, yet employees believe they are progressive and cutting edge.  Employees in Oregon have tenure of 20 years of more and they jump from role to role even though they don't have the market experience or skills.  Many brag they never had to interview for their roles which is not surprising based on the fact that they do not possess the skills or experience to succeed in the role.  Definitely not a meritocracy.  Cronyism and nepotism at its worst.  Common to see married couples, siblings, and children work together. Horrible experience for new employees like myself who have market knowledge and expertise, but who are abused by employees who steal their work and who view the new people as competition to beat because of the messed up focal process.  Not a good company for newcomers, but best for those who have worked at Intel  forever.  They convince themselves that it is the best company on the planet even though they have never worked at any other company but Intel.

review_title: Loved the company, but not this department
pros:
- High salary with great compensation
- Almost total freedom outside of working hours
cons:
- Bad career building opportunity, if you are an IT grad with an interest in a specific field, try getting into the field asap and gain experience, don't bother wasting time in this department because what you learn is 95% not applicable outside of Intel (Intel propiertary knowledge, not general knowledge) and you will have to start all over again as fresh grad if you decided to leave and pursue another field.
- Harsh working schedule. Despite the great salary, the schedule is very rough. Weekly day and night shift rotation is not suitable for most normal human beings and most people don't join in the first place is because of the schedule.
- Workplace is very biased and pretty toxic. If seniors don't like you in the first sight, you are just going downhill from that point. Words will spread and you will be targetted. Don't expect friendly seniors, they will mostly teach you in a rude and harsh manner (sighing, yelling, scolding). They will justify these by saying they went through the same thing (nice working environment huh). Not ALL seniors are like this, there are some really awesome ones as well, but it just happens that my shift is a special one.

pros: Culture and work life balance
cons: Can't think some right now

cons: Not much scope for growth

cons: No cons or any disadvantages

review_title: A great company to work with.
pros: Good work and life balance.
cons: It's subjective to different individuals.

pros: Friendly Coworkers, WLB, treat you like a team member
cons: Virtual completely due to the (COVID)

pros: Great workplace culture at intel
cons: Pay scale and promotion not competitive

pros: Great work culture and opportunities
cons: Too much dependencies to grow

pros: Intel is a large company and you can always jump around if you don't like what you are doing.  What works in one group may not work in another. Problems in one group may not be problems in another.  There is always something new to learn about. Intel is the worlds largest chip company. If you want to learn about how to "ship" hardware, Intel is a great place to be. The work hours are generally much less than other high-tech companies (Apple, Google, NVidia) allowing you to have an outside life too. Groups usually do 40 hours where much of the others mentioned do 60+.  Soft drinks are finally free, but food is not subsidized.
cons:
1) You have to be a politician to succeed.  
2) The focal process (yearly employee evaluations) is broken. Your career development\advancement is largely controlled by your manager.  You manager controls what you and your peers work on. If your manager doesn't give you high-visibility, important work, your advancement chances are low.  You'll be in bad shape if you get stuck with a bad manager but that happens everywhere.
3) Re-orgs are constant. They occur yearly. The company can't seem to make up its mind with management structure. It's unlikely you'll have the same manager for more than a couple years.
4) Intel is an old-fashioned company. Cubes\walls are grey and boring.  They finally started offering free drinks.

pros:
Intel overall has decent benefits but the perks haven't lived up to the top 100 companies to work for in the last few years. There is a reason for that. 

Medical benefits are good and you get a choice of plans that fits your specific needs. However, what you pay our of your paycheck is getting worse every year but that may be in most companies. Paid personal time and vacation/holidays are on par with the average large company.

Stock Purchase Plan offered to employees and bonuses a few times a year. Retirement plans available. Career opportunities and growth are good depending on which field you are in.
cons:
Layoff's every few years due to corporate downsizing or group consolidation are a given. Under appreciated and no room for job growth if you are an admin. Work Life Balance only exists if you MAKE sure it does. Some managers will work their employees to death at Intel, so be careful. There is an expectation that you are available 24/7 via email/phone. 

Lack of communication and "large company disease" is prevelant here as in any large company. If you have a good manager, you are set, if you have a poor manager, watch out. Brutal "review" process on a yearly basis needs to be changed or eliminated all together.

review_title: Innovative, technical, and flexible workplace with lower management flaws
job_title: Component Design Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
Open and direct communication in between senior management and employees.  Every quarter CEO and multiple senior VP and business group leaders engage employees via open forums, webcasts, and business update meetings, where employees are free to ask whatever is on their mind.

Excellent benefits package (okay perhaps not compared to Google), with free dental plans, a wide variety of medical insurance plans, decent (but not free) cafeteria food, and very flexible (albeit sometimes demanding) work schedule.

Employees tend to stay for long term (a rarity in Silicon Valley), with most individual contributors being intensely technical and happy to help each other.  Innovation and creativity is generally encouraged and rewarded (although there are short-sighted lower managers throughout the company that just want to do as they are told and go home).  Higher level management is generally good, and underperforming managers and employees do get pink slips from time to time.
cons:
Lower management is full of undeserving and incompetent managers that cannot lead, communicate, or do technical work.  Most small managers rose through the ranks as Intel expanded throughout the 90s and early 2000s, and many cannot lead or even communicate clearly.

Career growth is limited, as Intel prefers to promote within, and with the company not expanding at the moment, it's next to impossible to move upward.

job_title: Senior Administrative in San Jose, CA
pros:
Flex Time which allows for Work/Life Balance
Free fresh fruit and beverages
Great vacation and sick time
4 week Sabbatical after 4 years of service or 8 weeks after 7 years.
Boss leaves me alone to do my job
Stock Options
Medical/Dental/Vision
International work environment 
Retirement
cons:
They need to pay their Admins better for all the work they do and there are so few of us to get the work done. 1 Admin for every 100 engineers. We juggle balls in the air all while walking and chewing gum and scheduling meetings and planning events. We are the ones who get things done. We are the ones who everyone comes to when they need help, yet we are the one group at Intel that is compensated at 32% below the National average for Tech Industry. That is disgraceful and shameful and needs to change, but I doubt it will unless more people speak out against this injustice. Other than that, it a great place to work. 

But we ALL have bills to pay, no one should be under compensated. It is not nice to discriminate against women.

review_title: An abrupt end to a long career
pros:
Always very challenging work -- Environment is typically very intense.   Its your responsibility to manage work/life balance.  They have a lot of very smart people to work with who have very high expectations, but it challenges you to become a better person.  I always felt like if there was an opportunity to make the process or situation better then you were empowered to make that improvement happen.  You just may have to overcome some hurdles from different managers.  They have done a better job of defining the decision makers though. 
If you like to drive projects/improvements and are data/results driven then this is the place for you.   
I learned a lot from the people I worked with over the years and I was afforded many different opportunities.  It's enabled me to have a very successful career.
cons:
The company has evolved from a work hard and have fun culture to just work hard.  Much more focused on cost than in years past. 
It's more challenging to be successful if you aren't an engineer or have an "engineering mentality"  
It has become much more political over the last several years.

review_title: Overall, a pretty good place if you match the culture.
job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Santa Clara, CA
pros: In finance, the rotation program plus the size of the company brings lots of different opportunities.  The more desirable jobs obviously have pretty tough competition internally when people rotate.  Work-life balance varies greatly between groups but finance overall seems pretty decent.  Senior management does a decent job at keeping communication lines open.  Compensation is pretty competitive.
cons:
Confrontational culture, some like it, some don't.  I personally would prefer a more courteous, friendlier environment.  Some jobs in finance, especially for kids coming out of undergrad, seem to be not that demanding.  This could be a plus or minus depending on your perspective.  As for me, I am constantly irritated by these junior analysts chatting and laughing constantly while I'm working my butt off.  

Advancement opportunities in finance are limited and moving up can be slower than what MBAs coming in might expect.

There are 2 types of cubicles, a normal sized one where you have some privacy (people can only see you if they poke their head in) and tiny 8feet x 6feet cubicles which are just terrible.  Actually, even worse, if you're on the 4th floor in the main HQ building, there are a lot of open work areas, which I guess would be even worse.

review_title: Use to have a good work culture, but thing have changed.
job_title: Graphics Hardware Engineer in Folsom, CA
pros: This was my dream company and I had pleasure working for this company for more than 8 years. It had good work life balance, other than 3-4 month of stressful work at the time of the product launch. Talented folks around you. Had a option of work from home on need basis (Not for all teams). This is typically a process oriented company and too much document and have good company polices. Here where the pros ends.
cons:
Intel work culture had changed drastically over years. Extremely difficult to grow in the organization. Over process oriented, nothing happens with out a meeting. Lots of meeting and emails. Use to have good work life balance, but things started slowly changing after 2008. 

After spending too many years it would be hard to find jobs outside Intel, as the technology you learn would be too specific to the Intel (this is specially if you work in the core team). There would few hands full of companies where your job profile would fit. 

Compensation is extremely low compared to the market. My salary was increased twice for the sake of market adjustment, but even then its still very low compared to the market of similar experience and job profile. 

Pay raises are very minimal or some time non-existent.

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros:
- open and direct communication
i love this the most. as long you are not offensive, people do listen.

- managers are all supportive
of course it is not the case for everyone.. but my manager, manager's manager are all supportive on your thoughts\ideas\concerns.

- perfect work-life balance
i seldom work over-time.. employees with kids love here.

- smart coworkers
you'll find the best hardware engineers here
cons:
- Office politics
it's everywhere and it controls everything. but it is a common issue among all medium\huge corporations.

- Very slow career progression
after grade 6, it takes ~5 years to move to next level, averagely.

- Some senior staff are rude and arrogant
if they dislike you, or think you'll threaten their position, you will find you are out of the game next day. a few senior engineers think they are on top of the world, with their outdated knowledge\skillset.

- Stupid stack-ranking review system
Microsoft has discarded it already.. Intel still has it.

- losing its mind in recent years
Intel has been stubborn and insists that "PC market is not decreasing and it is still strong!" and in 2016 senior management has finally realized they were wrong. but it is late enough.

- Horrible layoff in 2016
the layoff in 2016 is terribly managed. it is endless and there's no way to predict when next round is coming. A lot, i mean a lot of bright engineers have left Intel and joining competitors.

review_title: Company with great benefits for your family, a long term employer.
pros: Great benefits for your family, better than most companies. Sabbaticals with 2 months off paid every 7 years or the employee can take up to six weeks off with pay every 4 years. Employee can stay long term in this company if they work hard receiving good performance reviews year after year. Pay is pretty good, no complaints there. There are many great things about Intel's benefits, too many to list.
cons: Company has a lot of politics and training is not a focus for new employees. As a new employee, be prepared to seek out information on your own with limited amount of help from experienced employees, mentors are hard to find at Intel. If employed as a exempt employee, expect to work around the clock with very little work life balance. Also if hired as a non exempt night shift employee there is very little chance of ever being moved to a day shift position if the nights does not work for you. Until the employee has some health condition preventing them from working nights, management will not allow you to move to day shift most of the time. Something to keep in mind when they ask if you would be willing to work night shift when hired.

pros:
Best job I ever had, until upper management decided to use a criterion for reducing headcount that had never been used before, and it blindsided my boss, who was furious that I got laid off.  But up until that point, it was a great job, and a company that lived its values.  Now, not so sure about living the values now.

Benefits are great, it's going to be hard to find another company with as good benefits.  Pay was good, I was rewarded as long as I worked my tail off and neglected my family.  The people do live the culture and values, but upper management has demonstrated that they don't.
cons: They will work you to death, and expect it, although not say that.  If you don't mind sacrificing a good portion of your family time so that you can put in the hours that are needed to get the job done (not enough resources but ever increasing demand for output), then you will be rewarded.  But, is it worth it?

review_title: Over his head with an inadequately skilled, overly confident management team.
pros: Salary.  Very competitive in the non-Californian markets.  If you find the right group, you can get the chance to manage larger groups with big budgets.  You can specialize or generalize and you aren't really penalized for doing either.  Competitive package.  You'll be marketable coming out.  Stock purchase program is generous.  Work conditions can be very flexible if you work for the right manager.
cons: Frequent layoffs (or "redeployments").  Frequent reorganizations.  Senior management is challenged to understand how to run its business (the management team is made-up largely of marketing folks and engineers).  Frequent changes to the overall strategic direction of the company.  Tolerance for ambiguity.  Tolerance for lack of understanding of spending and controls.  Tolerance for mediocre quality managers.  Stovepiped operating groups.  Stigma of being an Intel employee - and former employees' sense of entitlement (often remarked about in certain circles).  "Constructive confrontation" is a value touted by the company, however challenging senior managers (often put on pedestals as gods) has to be done with extreme tact and care.

review_title: Intel a safe, solid place to work
pros: Its very flexible with work/life balance. Telecommuting is widely adopted and accepted, and it has a great policy with vacation time. People are generally smart and get along well, and as by far the leading company in the industry it opens a lot of doors if you ever decide to leave. Lot s of resources available, and easy to move to different divisions/jobs if you get bored or feel like you're stagnating in your current position. Overall, a great job.
cons: As such a massive sprawling corporation, its easy to feel like just a number (especially with all of the layoffs in the last ten years). The offices are all very uniform and look like prisons. For someone going into tech expecting the wacky google/ebay environment, you'll be severely disappointed. Its much more like Dilbert/Office Space. They're experimenting with new layouts which seem much more comfortable; it seems like a small quibble but try working in the same place for years and you'll understand how much your environment matters.....

review_title: On the surface fine, underneath lost
job_title: General Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Scale.  Invests in emerging tech like few others can (given amount of $ required to take a risk).  Despite everything, massively profitable.
cons: The company currently has at least two CFOs and no CEO.  CEO of Intel needs to be a position occupied by a person who has a technology vision for the future, and who is inspiring enough to rally the company to get there.  Not a CFO.  Also, company appears to be a mode of not wanting long-term employees and instead hiring outsiders only, outsiders that do nothing but talk down to long-time Intel employees.  Not good.  Not necessary.  Not right.  We need fresh insights.  We need outside talent to come in.  But, we can do that AND respect our past - AND respect the people who built this company.  I find it interesting how Intel spent 50 years building an innovation, profitability and manufacturing powerhouse, taking on and beating every almost every competitor.  Intel prints profit.  Yet, now we think it’s a sound strategy to hire the technology and business leaders from the companies whose tails we kicked for 50 years to come in and tell us how to do things right?  Say that out loud and see if that makes sense.

review_title: Good benefits but the work environment is toxic.
pros: Salary and benefits were excellent.  Flexible work schedule is a definite plus.  Company will provide training on the equipment and process by paying for vendor courses and the online training materials provide additional resource to get up to speed.  Networking with other engineers can provide a great knowledge resource if they have the time to train and/or help you with a project.
cons: The higher the grade level, the expectations increase tremendously and if your manager does not have your back, you will be thrown under the bus.  Culture of fear has resulted in bringing out the worst behavior in otherwise decent people.  Cooperation between departments has degraded over time and folks are protective of their turf and will often beat down projects on the basis that they 'just don't like them'.  Many co-workers are pitted against one another by their manager.  Managers play favorites and are often technical folks that are incompetent when dealing with personnel matters.

pros: Competitive benefits, lots of types of opportunities. You could work for Intel for 40+ years and never be bored. Technical and Management tracks are kept separate, so you can move up without losing your technical skills. Intel employs some of the most iconic leaders in technology development, and you really can go talk to them if you wanted to. Want to become a USB expert? You can talk to some of the formative people in most technology areas, and really get good insight. Besides people being busy, the open-door policy is pretty well respected (if you wanted to chat with a VP, you could simply send them a chat message).
cons: Very slow to change. Intel tends to throw money at the latest trend, and usually just a hair too late. Even though we are generations ahead of our competitors on raw silicon technology, we are not always the best at applying that to our customer base. If you're software focused, be prepared to be second-place to shipping silicon. For as big a brand as Intel is, it has serious challenges being "cool" to anyone other than core gamers.

review_title: Good but bad company to work with
job_title: Module Development Engineer in Chandler, AZ
pros: Slightly higher than average pay for your work if you are less than 10 years with the company. Definitely excellent as a starter company for college graduates, but certainly look elsewhere after your burn-out a few years in. Diversity initiatives are really excellent! You create your own environment for how involved with the company volunteering and programs you want to be in.
cons: Be ready to work like a dog in the TMG sector all while not getting the bonus or pay raise that you are promised when signing up for the company.  Minimal sense of employee retention based on actual performance. Management expects everyone in your team to boast about themselves as much as possible for minimal raises, if you even get any. The worst part in the yearly review system is that every manager has to choose an unsuccessful employee who didn't boast about their work or get along with their manager well enough.

review_title: Toxic culture and not likely to reform
pros: Benefits are great. Cool to be developing next generation technologies.
cons: Engineers are treated like garbage. Module engineers do very little development work and job is dominated by tedious, repetitive tasks that should have been automated years ago or should be done by technicians. No work-life balance. Every day I fear getting stuck in the fab and not being able to go home. 12-14 hour days are the norm and if you're pulled in to work over a holiday, expect to get at most 1 comp day for every 2 days you work.

pros: Good pay, benefits straight out of school. Work with top of line equipment.

review_title: Good company & benefits - can be hard on engineers in startups.
pros: Great benefits including health, wellness, new scholoarship program and free fruit!  Cutting edge company - makes the best chips in the world.  We love our fitness center with coaches, wellness center where we can see a doctor on the spot almost free and get prescriptions delivered.  My job also has a lot of flexibility - can work from home when I need to because of a sick kid etc.  Intel has paid for additional training for me and for other folks entire degrees or two.  If you are interested in managment - there are lots of opportunities to advance or move around.
cons: High stress company - especially in manufacturing.  If a technician - you will work 12 hour shifts and be in a bunny suit all day, if an engineer supporting a twenty four by seven operation can be very stressful especially in startup situations or in development.  May need to relocate to other sites permanently or temporarily.  Intel employees can be very direct and at times agressive and require fast action.  We are also having layoffs right now - this business is cyclical depending on consumer and business demand so I've seen 4 or so rounds of layoffs in my time at the company.

pros:
Those co-workers and managers who believe in doing the right thing and who want to teach you; 
Daily challenges that help you to develop new skills, think critically, and build an ever growing network of Intel peers.
There are high expectations of you, which keeps you on your toes.
Flexibility to manage own vacation, sick-time, and to work from home every now and then when justified; 
Free drinks, on-site cafe and gym, car charging stations, free fruit, green power, composting and recycle programs. 
Employee autonomy is pretty standard. Not much micro-management. 
Corporate charter flights allow for easy visiting of some Intel US facilities.

review_title: Intel Mobile Communications India Pvt. Ltd. @ CCG Bengaluru
pros:
Large and various online learning resources in diverse fields produced both in-house and third-party.
Work from home option for a day in a week.
cons:
My CCG team mates at IMC Bengaluru weren't willing to share their knowledge/experience with the engineering workflow, and so work is sometimes stagnated not necessarily due to lack of intellectual ability but often due to undue pressure to outdo one-another. I now think the incentive structure didn't favour behaviours of collaboration but rather it has put undue competition among team-mates.
My manager for whatever reason was not comfortable or supportive in providing the feedback from lower level to higher management related to compliance with engineering workflow.
Pure people managers don't want (or unable) to understand the intricacies of actual engineering work and are just hoping good results. It also appearerd to me that they just wanted to appear bossy, when their views/decisions were challenged in engineering meetings.

pros: It is exciting to be part of a Dow 30 component company, which is a leader in the high tech industry.  There is definitely the brand recognition and the cache that the name brings to the table.
cons:
The company is stretched so thinly, and the bad part is that it's like that in an unhealthy way.  For example, I worked for a group, which expected its employees to work pretty much about 60 hours per week to hit the goals.  Then in the same general area, there resided another group, whose employees were seen playing solitaire in the afternoons, because they had less work, expectation  and supervision.

During tough economic times, employees' sense of self preservation kicks into a high gear, and now not only are you working ungodly long hours with immense pressure to deliver results, but your immediate coworkers and peers compete against you due to the 360 feedback system, and there are plenty of people who did not hesitate to sabotage one's reputation to increase his job security.  This culture was considered the norm and the management turned a blind eye.

job_title: Software Development Engineer in Chandler, AZ
pros: Great benefits -- health, dental, vision, sabbatical (you have the option of every 4 years, taking 4 uninterrupted weeks of vacation on top of your regular vacation, or every 7 years taking 8 weeks off), bonding leave for new parents (both male and female, as well as adoptive parents) -- on top of maternity leave. Lots of opportunities to explore new roles -- you can take advantage of temporary development assignments or  internal job transfers (permanent). There are employee resource groups that help connect you with like minded individuals, and the volunteer and education/charitable donation matching from the foundation are matched 100% up to a certain dollar amount. Stock participation programs and the like are certainly things you can take advantage of.
cons: As with any large corporation, the asterisk indicates that depending on the team you work for, and the business unit you are in, organizationally, your experience can be drastically different. There is churn, you will certainly want to keep your resume updated, and skills fresh. It would be disingenuous to say that working here is perfect, but it is a good company to work for. Depending on what your skill set is, your options for mobility may be very limited, but if you are a technical employee, that should not be a problem.

job_title: Hardware Validation Intern in Chandler, AZ
pros: It wasn't very difficult to keep an eight to five schedule. Lots of times I would come in when I wanted and leave when I wanted.  People didn't seem to care when you worked as long as you were keeping up with the team and reporting on your projects regularly.  Really, it wasn't too difficult of a job.  There were also a number of good people to work with.  I felt like, as an engineer you get decent compensation for great work life balance, and a chance to be part of a well known company.  Everyone knows who intel is.  Looks pretty good on your resume.
cons: Many times the work was extremely technical to the point of being very boring.  I love to work on technical projects but it is really easy to lose a sense of the bigger picture while you're sifting through the weeds of a project.  I also felt like if I ended up staying at intel that there wouldn't be much opportunity for advancement.  I would probably have left to pursue a graduate degree (mba etc.) and intel doesn't really offer any sort of decent college reimbursement program, (at least at a school that I thought was worthwhile attending).  Some of the people were kind of weird as well.

review_title: They DO NOT care about their Engineers
job_title: Intel Process Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Money,  but that too is not that awesome considering there are very few growth opportunities for Engineers.
cons:
(1) If you are Engineer, you will get a pager 24/7
(2) Most employees are desperate to QUIT but are not able to because they are "international" and have visa issues. They get stuck and by the time they are eligible to apply anywhere else, its too late and their skills are too specific for any other company. 
(2) when you are "on call" for a week - you will be expected to stay up 7 am to 7am the next day, may be 1-2 hours of sleep in between if you are lucky for 7 days. Its wretched and you will feel considerably tired and yet no recognition will be awarded because there are several people at Intel are doing it as well. 
(3) They absolutely dont care about Employees' life. You will be expected to check your email during vacations. 
(4) If you are an Engineer, and you need to take off even 1 weekend to go out of town, you would need to arrange for a back up and explain your manager that you will be gone for a weekend and why. 

I am planning to change companies as soon as i can.

review_title: Great place to work but beware
pros:
Good work life balance.
Good compensation package.
Challenging and engaging projects.
Smart people to work with.
3 weeks of vacation, then 4 weeks after 10 years
4 weeks sabbatical after 4 years or 8 weeks after 7 years.
Good health insurance coverage.
Great place to work events.
Drinks, snacks and monthly birthday treats.
cons:
Some individuals may have some form of NPD making them hard to work with. Most people are nice and caring people and great to work with.
Sad thing is NPD people, those generally considered as jerks, are the ones getting promoted the fastest. You have to be a jerk to get promoted. The trick is, be nice to individuals, let them know that you are only putting an acting face in front of management, be a jerk to them and unnecessarily put them down to expose their flaws and show how you are superior in front of management. It's an act that pays off but some people get stuck in that rot and they become like that inside and outside the meeting room. If you don't speak up and let yourself be bullied around, you will end up doing all the work for the NPD people and almost never get appreciated or rewarded.

pros: Social package, comfortable office places, great culture
cons: It has almost all the disadvantages of the large company

cons: complicated human relationships as working in large group

review_title: Intel is a good place to learn and meet other people.  If you stay too long, you may end up overspecialized.
job_title: Senior Yield Engineer  in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Intel is a great place to learn about the semiconductor industry.  There are a lot of great employees with deep knowledge that can guide you.  The other smart people that you meet and make connections with are probably the best part of the job.
cons: You need to be flexible in your location preferences if you want to stay at Intel.  Most of the good technical jobs have left California for Oregon or Arizona.  You definitely can feel like a cog.  No one person is indispensable, everyone can (and eventually will be) replaced.  They hire a lot of recent college grads who stay 2-3 years max before moving on to something else and the endless churn can lead to a lack of institutional memory.  The larger management structure seems to be unable to plan the correct amount of factory capacity or deliver  products on time that work the first time.

review_title: Intel is a good company with a solid foundation.  Be prepared to work hard (and toss a coin to be compensated for it)
pros: Good work life balance and opportunity to learn and excel your knowledge.  The company is truly committed to making this world a better place.
cons: Slackers that complain get just as much chance at raises than the hard workers do.  It all depends on the manager and how well you can write down a few accomplishments.

review_title: Numerous marketing resources and career development, willingness to share knowledge across product groups.
pros: Very good to excellent employee/family benefits and compensation package including 8 week sabbatical every 7 years, higher education benefits, and support for volunteer and community activities.  Because of Intel's R&D efforts, it was always likely that they were aware and monitoring numerous industries that could benefit from hardware and software technology.  Most managers are open to creative solutions to achieve your results, especially when you "thought outside the box".
cons: Although you may have invested your heart and soul into a program or project, upper management would only consider the financial risk when deciding what products to keep and what products to cancel.  They are shortsighted when it comes to making "Go" or "No Go" decisions, even if they had invested millions of dollars into a program. Programs would be canceled, and occasionally would be revived one or two or a few years later, but not necessarily benefiting from what was learned the first time around.

job_title: Applications Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros: Great culture and diversity in work and high responsibility.
cons: Slow progression and very large company.

pros:
Lots of opportunities
Good pay
Strong work ethic
cons:
Sometimes work is repetitive
Competition is high

job_title: Product Architect in San Jose, CA
pros: GPTW, lot of benefits, work life balance
cons: Less exposure to different teams apart from your

pros: good environment to work here
cons: Good cafeteria to eat here

review_title: Intel has good jobs and bad ones but overall a great company
pros: Good benefits & pay; Intel does amazing things and it's cool to be a part of; many coworkers are pretty incredible, smart people; since Intel is so big there is a huge variety of opportunities; people are generally very approachable (you can setup a meeting with anyone and talk to them no matter how high their position).  In most jobs you can tell your manager what flexibility you need in order to have good work-life balance.
cons: Some managers are bad and will work you to the ground, micromanage you, or focus on office politics.  If you get one then find another Intel position with a better manager (and a better second-level manager).  If you don't like any of the jobs in your whole division look in other divisions.  Some people get pretty stressed out about the annual reviews & ratings but if you have a good manager there won't be surprises and it will be fine.  There are always some people who get bad ratings but people are rarely fired if they partner with their manager to try to improve and if they don't do something very bad like violate IP rules or safety rules.

job_title: Human Factors Engineer in Folsom, CA
pros:
Intel gets its share of lumps for being a corporate behemoth. However being large comes with great advantages. Let's start with a paid sabbatical every 4 or 7 years. I have met many people from many different companies, and hands down, this is an awesome perk. Some other advantages include:
- Free fruit & drinks
- Generous salaries
- modern workspaces (some would argue this is a bad thing, but not me)
- frequent tickets to events

I know if I left Intel, I'd likely regret it. We just have it too good here... I hope this workplace continues to value the benefits of a "great place to work".
cons: It's a large Fortune 500 company, which means the wheels move slowly. Red tape seems to be common around here, so the people who truly get things done are the ones that don't necessarily conform to rules all the time. Re-orgs are a very common fact of life in a large company, which could get you lost in the shuffle, depending on your role.

pros:
- open and direct culture --> yearly evaluation with truthful feedback from top to down; you also have a say without pressure
- US-based MNC --> able to work with people from different geographies --> excellent exposure for personal development
- business is very diversified  - it is not only about CPU right now but Intel is everywhere involving technology. You got to learn a lot about tech
- excellent work-life balance --> work outside of office is possible with manager's permission
cons:
- evaluation is compared to peers with the same grade so promotion is not guaranteed even with  hard work exerted over a year
- (from my experience/group only) too focused on strategy and anything you do unrelated to strategy seems to be nothing
- following up on above point, your prospect is somehow limited by your job role - if your job role is too process-driven, you are placed at a lower level (again, from my experience/group only)
- position/sites rotation is key to promotion which gives you the fastest track to higher grades, but you got to be very mobile (actually good for people who are mobile but it poses a concern on those who are themselves immobile)

review_title: Intel pros and cons - good place to work or not?
pros: On the average, Intel is a nice place to work! It has a multi cultural and diversity program that promote cooperation and acceptance of differences, therefore greater team work. The paid for most jobs are fair and decent. Managers are rate by their staffs who work for them and it has been noted that this evaluation has made better managers. Promotion are base on performance, not seniority.
cons: The job performance rating include outstanding, beyond expectation, successful and improvement required. This rating sometimes finds it very hard to promote sincere hardworking people. For example, if you work very hard and do what you are required to do quickly and with quality results, a successful rating will be the norm. To get beyond expectation, one might need to do a lot of extra work and onetime someone get a this promotion because that person was doing two man job. Career development is encouraged at Intel, quite a few employee get their MBA degree while working full time at Intel and the cost of the education is pay for by Intel.

pros: Stability, Pay, no lack of new exciting work
cons: Politics, very slow growth, management not supportive

pros: Good Work life balance, Supportive Team, good place to learn
cons: I don't see downside working at Intel

cons: Politics, very slow growth, management not supportive

review_title: Good tech company to work with lot of life balance

review_title: Working as RTL/SoC Integration Design Engineer

review_title: It's not about how good the company is but rather how good the manager is!
job_title: Graduate Technical Intern in Hillsboro, OR
pros:
As a past intern at Intel I would say Intel truly is a great place to work. (Or maybe I was very lucky to be on a team with a manager who made it that way!).

I came to know a lot of nice people through group meetings and team lunches. My manager was very positive about me getting to know the company on my own, as well. I was given 100% ownership on some of the projects that I worked on and I enjoyed working on this culturally and geographically diverse team.

The team manager is by far the best I have known (compared to reports from interns working with different groups and teams at the same time). To recall one small incident, even though he clearly did not have to, my manager offered to part with some of the team's travel budget for that quarter (which by the way was in the negative) to cover my travel expenses for a full-time job interview scheduled at Intel's other site.

All in all it was a great first experience to work at a big company like Intel and I would work for this manager any day.
cons: I was only there for 7 months and frankly I could not find anything wrong with the team or the company.

job_title: Senior Process Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Good place to work. Great people who are very smart, logical and career oriented. Engineers and people with an analytical bent of mind will enjoy it here. Senior leadership is still very smart and goal oriented. Recognition and feedback are instantaneous in both work and outside situations. The company as a whole has a great sense of responsibility towards community as evidenced by the million man hours donated to local communities. There is a sense of respect and fairness among employees even when they disagree in work environment. Constructive confrontation is practiced in the company and mostly employees are respectfult to their co-workers.
cons: New hires will not find a work/life balance. Also it is difficult to rise up in the company and takes a lot of time and luck even when reviews are seemingly meritocratic. Compensation and benefits were low as compared to the industry but nowadays they have strived to catchup and beat the industry.Work/life balance especially for the new hires in the manufacturing and design environment is not present. They usually end up working greater than 80 hr work weeks and weekends. A maniac push towards the cutting edge technology and pursuit of moore's law exists and it takes a toll on the employees.

review_title: Advancement Takes a Long, Long Time
pros: They started the 12-hr. shifts with mandatory group calisthenics, done for about 10 - 15 minutes, an interesting concept to help prepare workers for long 12-hr. shifts of standing the whole shift.
cons: Worked in an Intel 300mm wafer Fab as a Manufacturing Technician. Semiconductor Fab Manufacturing Techs were assigned only 1 - 2 processes to do for a entire 12 hour shift, and would not be allowed to cross-train into other processes for up to 2 yrs. In other Semiconductor Fabs, 2 yrs. would be adequate time to cross-train across multiple manufacturing platforms. It takes a very, very long time to become thoroughly trained in the Fab at Intel; they are way too overboard in their drive to be sure Techs know "how to do it right" before advancing the Techs. The excessively lengthy time for cross-training results in burnout and disproportionate competition amongst the Techs. For that reason, I left Intel for better, much more progressive Semiconductor Fab opportunities.

review_title: 12 years, oh was it a ride...
pros: I was hired right out of college. Intel 100% funded my masters degree. Had to pull some strings within management, but it was a great benefit. Key takeaways: Intel is on the edge for employee educational development, provides competitive wages, and promotes a structured approach to IT operations. Ease of services and elimination of waste is strived for. It was black and white regarding hierarchy and organization structure.
cons: Internal business politics was complex. Internal operations at times lack tactical alignment with strategies. At times, numerous fronts led to multiple competitive venture capitalist paths colliding in different departments. ROI justifies decisions. Things move very fast. Constant high stress levels and a culturally aggressive persona is normal. Focal annual review was ineffective. Justification for existence seemed Darwinistic, based primarily on managerial opinion to determine where ranking and rating stands within the distribution. With a good talk, leaders are well rewarded. Good supervisors had to debate well to justify funding raises, etc. Virtual workplace with multiple different regions made work at time erratic. Work Life Balance wasn't easy with a family.

pros: Work life balance and good culture
cons: Salary is just so so compared with Internet company

pros: impactful working environment, international business environment
cons: Hard to manage your family/working balance

pros: Flexibility with Quality of work
cons: nothing specific to add on

review_title: Uncertain future for US engineers @ Intel
job_title: Design Engineering Manager in Hillsboro, OR
pros: If you live in Oregon and are an electrical engineer then there are not a lot of options - Intel is the best from a very small selection.
cons: Most of the interesting engineering work is being done outside the US - China, India, Israel, etc...  Continuous pressure to move engineering work outside the US - either Israel expansion or low-cost geo.  Polarization between marketing and engineering.

pros: I may be wrong about my feedback about the Management, but not all Managers are equal. After all its a good place work. It is all depends up on how is your project manager. I would tell, Wireless division is one of the worst division in whole company. If you are ok to make falls praise of Managers and keep holding their hands despite of multiple mistakes, under performing management team, then this is the right group to work with. The other groups are good to work with and a good potential of growth. Good work and life balance.
cons: Don't fight with the management team. By Indian in nature, it may lead to a lot of political issue than professional it the fight hurting their ego.

review_title: A great company for computer engineers &  chipheads thats heading into rough weather
pros: Intel has traditionally been a great company for computer hardware engineers wanting to have a long term technical career path. Can have an impact on technology that touches most people in the world. Usually affords a good work / life balance and good benefits. Intel's process technology lead might  help insulate it from currrent business environment.
cons:
Intel is currently heading into a uncertain business environment as it faces challenges from the  mobile and tablet segments of the market encroaching into its bread and butter notebook/client processor business. Due to this uncertain environment, there might be cutbacks or change of focus in the jobs positions at Intel.

Uncertain economic conditions the slow growth also have meant no stock growth in a decade with smaller budgets for raises and promotions. Mid-career growth opportunities have been very few.

review_title: Top folks are really great, but a lot of deadweight and politics
job_title: Principal Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
Good pay when you factor in the EB. Though they've started to cap the EB percentage.
The top 10% are really smart, the next 15% are pretty good. If you can work in a group with these people, your mind will be engaged and you will learn a lot.
Pretty good benefits, but not quite on par with Google, Microsoft, Apple, etc.
Extremely good CPU architects.
cons:
The remaining 75% are "meh".
Very, very political. If you tread on the wrong territory, even unknowingly, your project will be killed and your career possibly ended. 
Very silo'ed...product strategies look like congressional districts. Turf wars abound.
Software org is a mess.
Promotion to Principal Engineer and above is difficult (as it very well should be), but sometimes, unfortunately, politics plays a role.

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Folsom, CA
pros:
It is a big company, and there are many teams working on exciting stuff. If you find the right team you can learn a lot at Intel. 

You can work on cool cutting edge technologies, often 4-5 years before they make it out in the market.
cons:
First line management are basically failed engineers (generally speaking). These guys couldn't cut it on the technical ladder, took a day long management course, and think they are good to go as managers. My manager is just terrible technically, which makes for a horrible time at focal (performance appraisal). How can he judge my contributions relative to others, when he has no clue what is involved?

Lot of senior management is leaving Intel. Middle managers are ok, but generally seem to be lacking direction. Passdowns from senior to mid to lower levels doesn't happen very well.

Horrible pay (relative to peers in the industry). Recognition during focal is based mostly on seniority, even though Intel is supposed to be meritocratic. I finally left for Google, and my total compensation literally doubled.

pros: salary, development opportunities, benefits, people, culture
cons: processes, US centric, promotion process

pros: employee friendly and stable company
cons: too many meetings and org changes

pros: Good perks and benefits, decent pay
cons: Very bureaucratic, went through 3 rounds of layoffs in 2 years

job_title: Soc Design Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Great WLB. Ability to do internal transfers.
cons: Not really have anything to share.

pros: Great place to work , Flexi timing
cons: Not a good place to start your career with

pros: very good company with strong managers
cons: low salary compared to others companies

pros: Team Exposure Transparency at its best.

review_title: Ten years and the party was over a long time ago
pros: As an MT (Manufacturing Technician) in Development side of TMG, I can say the compressed work hours offer sufficient work life balance given the number of days off to do whatever else you want with your life.  Add vacation time and paid absences to that and you have more than enough "free time" to be the envy of many working people around the world.  Overall, work environment is safe and clean (obviously).
cons: If you are in the lower echelon of pay grade, better pay and raises may be something left to be desired.   Focal and reviews are rather dubious.  Bonuses and other perks aside from corporate EBs are a joke.  Engineering dictates, period.  Every year seems importance of internally trained skilled technicians are being less valued and deemed irrelevant and obsolete since they are being treated more like factory operators since Intel relies more from contracted Field Service Specialists.  Advocates a lot of values that made the company what it is but in recent years does not practice what it tries to preach.   Top executives seemed to lack in leading by example (hence lawsuits in public news).

pros: Almost everything of importance depends upon which organization you are in (Intel is a ~100k employee company) and your relationship with your manager, but some of the foundational elements which make Intel a great company include a meritocratic approach to compensation and promotion (you *earn* your raises and promotions; your title, time of service, who you know, etc., are irrelevant), stock options and/or restricted stock for almost all employees, multiple bonuses each year (mostly based on business conditions), flexible work hours, solid technical infrastructure (laptops that work and are refreshed regularly, a reasonably reliable network and email and VPN), advanced productivity tools (Lync 2013, SharePoint, full BYO mobile support), solid compensation, the opportunity to do almost anything you can dream of within one company (people can have 3+ "careers" and never leave Intel), and how can you forget to mention sabbatical (8 weeks paid every 7 years of service, on top of regular vacation time).
cons: Almost everything of importance depends upon which organization you are in and your relationship with your manager. If you have a lousy manager, you will not be happy. As a geographically dispersed teams, many groups have regular early morning and late night meetings, and usually, those are on top of your full day in the office. Mostly, work-life balance is paid lip service - what *really* counts is delivering results.

pros: established, industry leader, takes good care of its employees overall
cons: large companies tend to have such deep organizations sometimes communicating the goals and objectives rolling down through the ranks gets lost or unclear. Re-deployments are frankly a failure of management hiring too many people to consistently keep employed though failed programs or industry ebbs and tides. This creates a churn cycle and affects many peoples lives. Its been very consistent so obviously an issue to someone looking to have a career who can get catch in these cycles.

job_title: PTD Module and Integration Yield Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Great co-workers, good pay, good locality, everyone is hardworking and lots to learn. Everyone has more things on their plate than they can carry...so work is never ending so should know how to take your time off before you get burnt out
cons: Bureaucracy, the company doesn't care about the employees, we had a new manager to our group and he had a very bad track record, 8 engineers left his group in less than an year and also heard of a rumor that he asked one of his engineers for a 1:1 meeting at around 1:00am to make her take responsibility of his mistake. I had some very bitter experiences with him as well. He screwed up my focal and got fired due to mass lay offs. I appealed my layoff and also had many email exchanges with the HR but was of no use. It's very interesting that the management backs this manager who has a track record of losing about 10 engineers within one year. They treat every employee as a machine. No work life balance and too much politics. Focal is a joke..they just give good numbers for those who are in good looks of the manager. If you are not in good books of your manager just get transferred to other group or look for another position. They just scheduled a 1:1 and told that I am fired. They did not even let me come to my cubicle.

pros:
AWESOME benefits (stock, health, paid family leave)
Sabbatical (every 4 or 7 years)
Ability to rotate into different jobs, organizations to build your skills & expand career options
Focus on work/life balance - allowing flexible workhours, open doors to discuss issues, some jobs ebb and flow with workloads
cons:
Large company makes for difficult to impact change - lots of people/orgs to influence, POLITICS get in the way
Difficult to do business for customers - so customer facing jobs are that much harder (more selling to do within the walls of Intel than outside of Intel)
Lots of pet / science projects being done - with resources invested - that eventually get killed - should've kept the resources on the money making projects
The recent layoff is causing existing employees A LOT of pain (work has quadrupled, expertise is gone, products no longer being developed/supported upsetting customers, lack of trust - fear it will happen again)
The "focal" annual review process needs an overhaul - to much politics involved

pros:
People who like the classic big business style of working will thrive
Pay and benefits are decent, but saw them decline during my tenure
There are career opportunities for those willing to work extremely hard
For those who like domestic and international business travel, you will be given opportunities
cons:
The workload is usually huge, and the company culture frowns upon dropping tasks when overburdened
A great deal of bureaucracy and politics to wade through. Expect to spend a lot of time pandering to your manager's ego if you want to get anything done.
Speaking out against Intel policy, culture or working style is a quick way to get made redundant.
Intel are quick to drop employees if they can get cheaper labor in other countries, or by consolidating. The effort to redistribute those impacted is mostly lip service.
Work-life balance is particularly limited by the fact that HQ in the US usually refuse to talk at mutually convenient times, which means lots of late night and early morning calls.
Some entry-level roles require regular public holiday working (extra compensation is provided however)

pros: Great Company to work in Hyderabad
cons: Larger teams to work with much inter depedencies

pros: very good college . nice peopke
cons: the money isnt good enoth

pros: work life balance is really great
cons: compensation is less than peers

job_title: Product Development Engineer in Folsom, CA
pros: Good work environment, will recommend to my friends.
cons: I feel it is good!

pros: interesting work, plentiful parking, competitive salaries
cons: quite far from everything else in the city...

review_title: Welcome to Intel, leave your life at that door.
job_title: Senior Process Engineer in Portland, OR
pros: The overall pay and benefits package is actually quite nice and the actual work done can be very rewarding.  Having medical, dental, and vision helps out a lot these days.  The total package also includes bonuses twice a year, stock bonuses once a year, and resonably nice 401k program.
cons: Work life balance is given lip service only.  Senior management is always talking about it being a core value, but middle management completely ignores it.  Communication from upper management is also lacking. How would you like to be a middle manager with 20 years at the company and be told when you show up for work that you no longer have a job because of unannounced layoffs.  Better yet, how would you like to get a call while you are on sabbatical and be told that once you come back in two weeks, you will be unemployed because of those same layoffs.

review_title: Good company, but working in the PTD fabs is rough
pros: Working as an engineer in PTD has amazing job security with a decent salary. You are also helping to develop the next generation of computer chip, which is pretty neat in an abstract sense.
cons: There is no real opportunity for career advancement, there are relatively few transferable job skills, work-life balance is terrible (24/7 on-call support), the pay isn't great compared to the number of hours worked or the possibilities at your skill level, and you don't feel like you contribute meaningfully most of the time because you are such a small cog in such a big machine. Oh, and because much of what you do is IP-protected, it can be hard to tell anyone what you've done on, say, a resume for another employer.

job_title: UEFI FW Developer in DuPont, WA
pros:
I'm referring to the DuPont site in particular, so my comments and ratings are with respect to my group and/or campus:

In my particular group WLB (work life balance) is great and work load is fair. Hot issues tend to be identified early on, avoiding frequent "dungeon environments where we work every day for 12 hours, at least.
cons:
The DuPont site underwent recent downsizing, so it's a bit scary/uncertain in terms of long-term job security. My group leaves more to be desired in terms of group morale. Other groups I have worked in the past got along extremely well, and it resulted in great synergy in our "day-to-day's" as well as during stressful/work-intensive times. My current group is primarily comprised of introverts that are pretty much "all business". The occasional "how's it going?" as you cross paths in the hallways is about as much conversation we have outside of meetings or other work-related gatherings.
One other thing, from what I hear, the pay scale doesn't compare to the other hi-techs up in Seattle.

review_title: The company not to be trusted anymore
pros:
Great work-life balance: you are not expected to sit at work for 8 hours every day; noone counts the amount of time spent in the office (like some companies do).  
Competitive salary and good compensation package.
Great people that you can learn a lot from.
cons:
Limited career growth opportunities: the only way to get higher position is to quit the company, work for some other employer and only then you may have a chance to find better opportunity within Intel (if there's no hiring freeze, restructuring, etc, etc...).
Company management doesn't value its employees and in the tough times it easily gets rid of great engineers and other experts.
Unclear directions and communications from senior management - it's hard to understand company strategy and how you can contribute to overall success.

review_title: After 14 years in Intel, my opinions are ...
job_title: Graphic Design Manager in Sacramento, CA
pros: Cutting edge technology and project challenges; medical and insurance coverage; flexi working hours and locations; free fruits/drinks; smart and sharp co-workers around which we learnt from each other; sabbatical benefits; bonuses
cons:
Compared to the first day I joined Intel in 2001, a lot of changes have happened this company but are mostly going downhill in my opinion.

- The top management of Intel seems to be losing direction on the next big thing - numerous attempts/acquisitions but none of them, so far, turns out to be huge to the company
- Compensation and benefits have either gone flat or deteriorated
- Stagnant stock prices < $40 (since early 2000s)
- Unrealistic work loads due to number of overlapped projects - up to 5 (in my team)
- People development in my organization is lack off
- Brutal performance ranking system which is needed to remove non-performing employees but many times i saw the ranking was done based on "impression". Meritocracy is not always applied
- Lower than market base pay esp. at lower grade level
-  Spent $$$ to recruit from external to join senior/top management committee but none so far has made big impact to the company.

pros: Best company for India in

pros: You can do work from home
